entry.title: SITLON 2025 - Segurança em Aplicações/Serviços no BTP em épocas de IA, e toda sua história/evolução!
entry.content:
Hello World! Tudo bem?

Após o encerramento com sucesso do primeiro SAP Inside Track Londrina (2025), que foi um evento somente presencial e contou com muitas apresentações de qualidade, resolvi criar esse material aqui na comunidade para aqueles que não puderam comparecer pessoalmente. 

Então segue a apresentação do conteúdo do SIT Londrina 2025, em formato "Live":

Mas se ainda não se contextualizou, sugiro antes de assistir o material acima ler todo o conteúdo abaixo e entender a evolução até o evento SIT Londrina 2025, ok?

Se você não conhece SAP e chegou até aqui, segue um pequeno resumo:

SAP é um software de gestão empresarial usado pelas maiores e mais importantes empresas do mundo para integrar e otimizar processos de negócios cruciais, como finanças e logística. Ele centraliza dados para fornecer uma visão completa e em tempo real, permitindo decisões estratégicas mais rápidas e eficientes. A sua importância reside em ser uma espinha dorsal tecnológica que garante a eficiência e a competitividade global dessas corporações.

No evento, realizei a apresentação “Segurança em Aplicações/Serviços no BTP em épocas de IA” sobre Cyber Security no mundo SAP, para aplicações desenvolvidas em um modelo bem específico. Mas com esse post aqui, o objetivo é atingir e disponibilizar o conteúdo a todos da comunidade SAP, bem como os curiosos e interessados pelo tema de segurança da informação. Como muitos podem estar lendo pela primeira vez sobre o tema e o que eu já fiz até então, vou detalhar a historia desde o começo de uma maneira resumida até chegar no SIT Londrina 2025, ok?

Tudo começou na Pandemia, no ano de 2020/2021, onde estava fazendo uma pesquisa para um blog que iria escrever sobre um tutorial de um tipo desenvolvimento Web especifico (SAPUI5) . Esse tutorial seria sobre o desenvolvimento de aplicações UI5/FIORI ao publico B2C, ou seja usuários que em sua maioria nunca teriam visto nada sobre SAP e que para eles seria como uma aplicação Web qualquer, também aplicações essas que seriam disponibilizadas na internet para acesso do publico em geral. No Blog eu iria abordar a arquitetura recomendada, exemplos de códigos fonte, etc., porém na etapa de pesquisa para apresentar alguns “exemplos” já existentes no mercado, me deparei com cenários muito assustadores!

Para contextualizar, “o sistema SAP” sempre é em sua maioria um sistema “fechado”, onde o acesso é feito geralmente por quem de fato precisa do mesmo (até por questão de custo de licença). Analisando a minha experiencia, de colegas e muitos estudos, conseguia afirmar então que os profissionais que desenvolvem, desenham e/ou especificam soluções SAP ao “publico geral”, em sua maioria não tem uma preocupação com os quesitos de segurança. No mundo SAP, os desenvolvimentos geralmente ficam dentro do sistema e/ou na rede interna do cliente, então esse tópico nunca foi muito explorado pelos profissionais e consultorias que desenvolvem soluções customizadas, e esse aqui foi o principal motivador de iniciar todo o conteúdo. Ou seja, profissionais do mundo SAP precisam se atentar e se preparar ao criar soluções desse tipo, pois os impactos de não fazer algo correto podem ser enormes (que verá logo mais alguns exemplos). Pois se algum desses casos caísse nas mãos erradas, não só a imagem da empresa em questão que usa SAP, independente do país que está localizada, seria impactada com prejuízos financeiros e até implicações legais, mas nós profissionais do mundo SAP também seriamos impactados pela “imagem” que seria passada que o sistema SAP é de alguma maneira "inseguro".

Antes de entrarmos no detalhe tenho que falar algo importante, tudo que falarei daqui em diante diz respeito a aplicações/serviços customizados e não standard SAP, ou seja foram soluções desenvolvidas por alguém para atender o requisito daquele cliente em específico, e não algo que “vem” no produto SAP. Soluções SAP a nível de produto no geral são muitos seguras, onde a mesma investe muito para manter o mais alto nível de segurança, utilizando todas as ferramentas e métodos de mercado para tal. Até ter programas onde pode “contratar” profissionais de cyber segurança para tentar explorar e descobrir como deixar seus produtos mais seguros (onde eu posso ou não ter participado. NDA). Recomendo os links 1 e 2 para quem deseja se aprofundar mais no tema de segurança no nível de produto SAP. Outro ponto importante, é que demonstro como essas aplicações customizadas podem ser facilmente encontradas na internet por ferramentas como Google Buscador. 

Na pesquisa fui encontrando muitas empresas vulneráveis em um numero altíssimo, quase podendo afirmar que mais 30% das que encontrei, tinham algum problema. Então o que era um tutorial mudou para uma pesquisa mais aprofundada do tema, e com isso resolvi criar o movimento #SafeSAPUI5. Que basicamente iniciaria com a criação de material e conscientização dos profissionais para termos aplicações e serviços SAP seguros que estão expostos na internet. Pois aqui entra um detalhe técnico bem agravante, para muitos casos o requerimento do cliente (ou seja, o que ele precisa) é ter uma aplicação customizada porem sem ter a necessidade de nenhum tipo de autenticação por parte do usuário que vai acessar. Ou seja, ao clicar na URL ele já deve entrar na aplicação customizada e poder fazer a ação necessária, cenário esse que foge bem do “padrão” SAP e existem muitas e muitas aplicações como essa espalhadas pelo mundo.  

Os materiais do #SafeSAPUI5 podem ser encontrados aqui.

Além dos mesmos, como já estava pronto para escrever, resolvi criar um Ebook gratuito sobre o tema, juntando um pouco de historia, exemplos, dicas e casos reais. Com isso, nasceu o ebook UI5 Hacker, que pode ser encontrado gratuitamente aqui (Português e Inglês). 

Juntando tudo isso apresentei a primeira palestra do tema, ainda na Pandemia, no evento UI5 Con 2021 (em Inglês) que é a conferencia global de SAPUI5, biblioteca utilizada para realizar esses desenvolvimentos (mais detalhes na palestra ou ebook).

UI5CON 2021: #SafeSAPUI5: 

Depois da mesma, com a ajuda da própria SAP, consegui espalhar essa conscientização e também comunicar os clientes ao redor do mundo que estavam inseguros e foram citados nos exemplos da palestra e ebook (alguns com vulnerabilidades muito graves, como cópia do passaporte de todos os usuários pronta para ser extraída por exemplo). Importante, era possível conseguir isso sem precisar realizar nenhum tipo de hack, apenas saber executar um serviço/API que está exposto na internet (até pelo próprio navegador). 

Então em 2023, resolvi fazer um compilado do material de 2021 em Português (com alguns novos exemplos) e apresentar no SIT SP 2023 (Serviços Seguros & Aplicações Seguras), trazendo a tona novamente o material e o tema (agora focado mais em Português).

A palestra pode ser vista no Youtube aqui:

Com isso tive muitos feedbacks positivos de profissionais e de clientes SAP que resolveram suas vulnerabilidades e passaram a adotar as praticas em seu dia a dia, para esse e outros requisitos. Mas é importante falar, é possível SIM fazer uma aplicação WEB como essa que descrevi acima de maneira segura e protegida para o seu cliente, só seguir as boas praticas e utilizar as ferramentas corretas. Acontece que nesse "meio tempo", a adoção do SAP BTP (oferta da SAP de serviços Cloud, assim como os outros grandes players de tecnologia) cresceu exponencialmente no mundo todo. Se iniciou então um movimento de muitos clientes para levarem suas soluções para o BTP (conhecido como o movimento “move to cloud”), e alguns deles com aplicações se enquadrando nas possíveis vulnerabilidades descritas. 

Mas e então, apenas levar as aplicações ao BTP as deixam seguras? 

E com a chegada, popularização e massiva utilização/evolução das Inteligências Artificiais (IAs) impactam nisso tudo?

Para responder as questões acima e trazer a tona novamente o tema, resolvi criar o material da palestra apresentada no SIT Londrina 2025: “Segurança em Aplicações/Serviços no BTP em épocas de IA”. Mas como comentei antes, o evento foi somente presencial e por conta disso resolvi realizar uma “live” com o mesmo material e conteúdo para disponibilizar a todos o mesmo. Colocando em uma linha do tempo então, ficaria assim:

O PDF do material apresentado no SIT Londrina 2025 pode ser encontrado aqui.

Após a apresentação desse material (PDF e "Live"), demonstro que uma simples ida ao SAP BTP com aplicações nesse modelo não te deixará mais seguro. E com a chegada das IAs, existe hoje uma rápida revolução no segmento de Cyber Security (assim como o mundo em geral) que as empresas que utilizam soluções SAP devem estar atentas e preparadas. 

Espero que tenha gostado do conteúdo e lhe ajudado, e que de alguma maneira tenha agregando algo ao seu conhecimento atual. 

Obrigado e nos vemos nas próximas aventuras do “Hacker do Bem”.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 6: SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur
entry.content:
This sixth post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur. For SAP Customer Experience, look at the new AI agents and the capability to build custom agents, plus AI innovations for marketeers in SAP Emarsys, and Joule and AI order summaries in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.  SAP Concur takes travel planning to the next level with the whole new travel experience, complemented by the new Joule Booking Agent enabling users to use natural language to book a trip.

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 

SAP Customer Experience

The user experience highlights I have picked are all AI-related:

  • AI Agents.
  • SAP Emarsys UX innovations.
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 UX innovations.

This news article summarizes what’s new overall for SAP Customer Experience, beyond UX-related innovations:

  • Connected for Growth: What’s New with SAP Customer Experience in Q2 2025.

AI Agents

As I explained in part 1 of this series, AI agents work in the background to give a greatly enhanced user experience. A number of powerful AI agents are available for SAP Customer Experience, via the package Joule Premium for Customer Experience. This blog post and video give a nice overview of three of them in action:

  • AI Agents in Action.
  • Video: See How AI Agents Streamline Customer Service (3:11 min.)

The latest UX innovations are:

  • Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant.
  • Digital Service Agent (via Early Adopter Care program).
  • Ability to create custom agents in the CX AI Toolkit.

AI Shopping Agent for the SAP Commerce Cloud Shopping Assistant

The shopping agent helps customers when visiting an online shop: they can simply use natural language to state what they are looking for, and the shopping agent will respond with suitable suggestions. Figure 1 shows an example, where the user starts out by stating that they are looking for shoes to wear for two mile long walks while wearing a suit. Two shoes are suggested, and the user asks which one is comfortable right away, since he doesn’t want a long break in period. The agent recommends one model, and the customer then asks for a recommendation for a belt to match, which the agent promptly gives him.

Figure 1: Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant from SAP Commerce Cloud. Alt Text: three screenshots of a tall and narrow screen showing a chat, one for each of the interactions explained in the main text. Each response shows one or two images: in the first case two shoes, then one shoe and then one men’s belt.

Find out more here, and watch the video embedded there to see it in action:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Shopping Agent

Digital Service Agent

The new digital service agent helps to provide your customers with a great user experience, similar to how the shopping agent is aimed primarily at your customers. It enables customers to ask questions with natural language and provides answers based on your company’s business knowledge residing in the SAP system. Hence, it is able to resolve common inquiries and issues, giving customers a good experience. Furthermore, by freeing up you sales and service team to focus on more complex inquiries, your customers will also receive a better service and hence better experience.

The digital serice agent is currently only available for select customers via the Early Adopter Care program. Figure 2 in the next section shows how these customers can select it in the AI Agent Builder.

Find out more here:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Digital Service Agent.

Create Custom Agents with CX AI Toolkit

You can now create your own custom agents with the CX AI toolkit. Figure 2 shows the start screen for the AI Agent Builder, where you can select “Custom Tool” to start the wizard which takes you through the steps to create a custom agent.

Figure 2: The AI Agent Builder in the CX AI Tookit for creating custom AI agents or using SAP templates to create AI agents. Alt Text: A screenshot with “Let’s Create AI Agents” in large text in the middle below an illustration, below in much smaller text “Start by selecting an Agent Template”. Below that, two rows of three cards representing Agent Templates are shown: Custom Tool, Knowledge Agent, Classification Agent, Digital Service Agent, Q/A Agent, and Shopping Assistant Agent.

Find out more here:

  • Documentation: Create a Custom AI Agent.

Further Information on AI Agents for SAP Customer Experience

For a deeper understanding of the power of these AI agents, have a look at this longer video:

  • Video: SAP CX AI Toolkit: AI Insights Agents for SAP C4C & Shopping Assistant | Product Inspiration Series (32:21 min.)

SAP Emarsys

AI-Assisted Report Builder using Natural Language

You can now easily create a report using natural language to describe what you are interested in. Figure 3 shows an example of the entry screen. At the bottom you see hints on what kind of queries you can enter.

Figure 3: AI-assisted report builder in SAP Emarsys. Alt Text: A screenshot with “Unlock the Power of Data with the AI-assisted Report Builder” in the middle. At the top a text entry field containing the query “What are the Sent, Delivered, Bounced, Opened, Clicked, Purchased, Unsubscribed, Complained for my Email campaigns in the past month?”, to the right an AI button “Generate Report”. At the bottom of the screen two example queries are listed.

Once you have created the report, you can easily adjust it using a set of convenient filters, such as the date range as well as the list of campaigns and metrics. Watch this video to see it in action:

  • Video: AI-assisted Report Builder (46 seconds).

AI-assisted Product Finder using Natural Language (Pilot)

Pilot customers can now try out the new AI-assisted product finder, which allows users to search for product to add to marketing campaigns using natural language. Figure 4 shows an example of how to enter your search text, see more here:

  • Video: AI-assisted Product Finder (38 seconds).

Figure 4: AI-assisted product finder available to SAP Emarsys pilot customers. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a screen with a left half containing the Product Finder, with a search field containing “Most popular shoes in the last 6 month”, above an empty space with the text “Welcome to Product Finder!” in the middle. The right half shows an image of someone dancing in the sun and an image of a dress, along with some describing text.

Read more about latest SAP Emarsys innovations here:

  • SAP Emarsys Q2 2025 Product Release.
  • SAP Emarsys introduces new generative AI capabilities in June Product Release

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Joule in SAP Sales Cloud

Joule is now available in SAP Sale Cloud Verion 2, helping users get quick insights, for example about an account. As you can see in Figure 5, these insights can be charts as well as text based.

Figure 5: Joule for SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot of Joule showing Customer Account Overview, with the text “Show Key Metrics” entered as chat, below which a card with a vertical stacked bar chart shows credit limit usage (remaining amount and exposure amount), below that a card showing Key Metrics (Activity) and part of a donut chart for Tasks, Phone Calls, Appointments, Visits etc.

Have a deeper look here:

  • Video: Intelligent Selling with Joule in SAP Sales Cloud & SAP S/4HANA Cloud | Product Inspiration Series (16:04 min.)

Sales Order Summary

The Sales Order Summary uses generative AI to summarize key information about the sales order, as well as including information about some changes, for example how the price compares to the original price. Figure 6 shows an example, with the insights shown on the left of the screen.

Figure 6: Sales Order Summary in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a sales order, with the left third showing an overview with AI-generated insights such as “13 days past requested date”, “Overall discount is EUR 808.55”. On the right, the Order Summary tab is shown, with account name, net and gross value, pricing stats, above “Products in Cart (2)” showing a list of two products, followed by the top part of a list of pricing steps.

Learn more here:

  • Documentation: Sales Order Summary.

 

SAP Concur

The new Concur Travel experience makes it much easier to book travel involving multiple bookings, such as a flight plus hotel plus rental car. And if you just need to book one item, you can do that very easily now with the new Booking Agent powered by Joule.

New Concur Travel Experience

When travelling for a few days, one often needs to book more than one item. A typical combination is booking a flight, a hotel and a rental car. Up until now, you have had to book each item separately and take care that the dates and time match. Now, with the new Concur Travel experience, planning and booking is much easier: you can enter the start and end dates for your flight, and the new feature Match Flight Booking is applied to the hotel and car, so that dates and time match automatically.

Figures 7 to 11 show what this looks like: Figure 7 shows the start screen, where you select which items you want to include (flight, hotel, car, train). Figure 8 shows the flight view, where flight dates have been entered. Figure 9 shows the hotel search, with the default selection “Based on flight selection”, and similarly Figure 10 shows the rental car search, with pick-up and return times calculated based on the flight schedule. Figure 11 shows the finalize screen, in this case showing that the flight and hotel has been selected but the rental car is still open.

Figure 7: New Concur Travel experience start screen. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over with a large image of a magnifying glass on a globe, above the text “Start Planning”. Below that four check boxes in a row: Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train, at the bottom “Continue” and “Cancel” buttons.

Figure 8: New Concur Travel experience screen with flight details. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a trip planning for a Trip to Las Vegas. The left third of the screen shows a list with items Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, with Flight selected. Below the list buttons “Add to trip” and “Search”. On the right a selector for round-trip (selected), one-way or multi-city, with fields for from / to locations and a date field for the stard and end date. To the right a button “Time preferences” and a drop-down for selecting “Cabin”.

Figure 9: New Concur Travel experience screen with hotel details. Alt Text: As for Figure 8, but with Hotel selected, and on the right Hotel Search displayed, with the fields for “Hotel, location, or name” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection”.

 Figure 10: New Concur Travel experience screen with rental car details. Alt Text: As for Figure 9, but with Rental Car selected, and on the right Rental Car Search displayed, with the fields for “Pickup” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection” and the field “Drop-off” filled with “Same as pickup”. Pickup Time and Drop-off Time fields have 10:00 AM entered.

Figure 11: New Concur Travel experience finalize screen. Alt Text: Screenshot showing “Trip to Las Vegas” on the left two-thirds, with a card summarizing the flight with United Airlines from San Antonio, TX (SAT) – Las Vegas, NV (LAS) and a card summarizing the hotel Courtyard by Marriott Las Vegas. The right third shows the Estimated Total Cost $2497.85 above a list with the cost of each item (flight, hotel, rental car), and buttons for “Finalize Trip” and “Cancel Trip”, and options to book anything else (Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train).

As you can see in Figure 11, another advantage of the new experience is that you get budget transparency at the trip level. Also, you have flexibility to book parts of the travel now and other parts later.

Technically it supports deep linking, which means that you can send a trip-level link to colleagues which includes all the trip parts, making it easy to coordinate trip planning when travelling with others.

To find out more, have a look at the

  • Documentation: Trip Planning in New Concur Travel.

Booking Agent in Concur Travel

The new Booking Agent lets you use natural language to book business travel which is compliant with company policy and budget constraints as well as taking into account your personal travel preferences.

Figure 12 shows an example where the user has simply stated “I want to book a flight from San Francisco to London on Sept 9th and back on Sept 13th”. The answer shown takes into account the user’s frequent traveler memberships, flight availability and company policies.

Figure 12: New Concur Travel Booking Agent in Joule. Alt Text: A screenshot of Concur Travel with Joule opened on the right, the content is explained in the main text, with the possible flights listed alongside a thumbnail image representing the airline “jetBlue”.

Watch it in action and find out more:

  • Video: Concur Travel – Booking Agent demo (2:33 min.)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Booking Agent.

 

Continue Reading - UX Innovations in UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile

I hope you enjoyed this sixth part, covering SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur, with great new AI-powered user experiences helping users work more efficiently and effectively.

Here is the link to the final part seven, covering latest innovations in UI design and technology for web and mobile:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
entry.content:
This seventh and last post in my series gives an overview innovations in our UI tools and technologies, making it ever easier to design, build and integrate UIs, for both web and mobile applications. For designing apps, web and mobile, we have a new SAP Design System portal and UI Kits in Figma. For developers, we have added further AI assistance, as well as many individual improvements, including support for the latest international accessibility standard WCAG 2.2. Fun fact: SAPUI5 is now used on all 7 continents – yes, Antarctica too! 

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

The above post also gives an update on building your own Joule agents, so I will not cover that here, but rather focus on web and mobile UI development.

 

Design News

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits in Figma

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

Figure 1: The SAP Design System portal start page. Alt Text: Image with header saying “SAP Design System”, with a “See what’s new” button below it, and then four subsections in a horizontal row: SAP Fiori for Web, SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for iOS and SAP’s Digitial Design System. A “Feedback” button is on the bottom right.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

Figure 2: SAP’s UI Kits for Designers in Figma. Alt-Text: The image shows two rows of four cards representing UI Kits: SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for Web, Designing for Performance, SAP Fiori for iOS, SAP Fiori for watchOS, SAP Fiori for Wear OS, SAP S/4HANA for Web, and Accessibility Design Tools. On the very left of the image information about SAP is listed, with links to resources such as www.sap.com/design-system.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite

Consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises. We have identified areas directly relevant to users and plan to introduce a number of design updates in SAP Fiori for web across our suite of products to further increase consistency.

The areas we have redesigned and which we plan to provide across our suite of products this year and next year are:

  • Shell bar (at the top of the user’s screen)
  • Navigation menu: side navigation (see Figure 3 below).
  • User menu
  • Notifications
  • Search in the shell bar

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition already supports the first four of these, you can have a look at them in part 2 of this series, in the section SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad.

As outlined in Part 1, SAP Build Work Zone standard edition also supports side navigation.

Find out more about these design updates here:

  • Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web).

We also provide designers with a refreshed new set of illustrations, to be used for illustrated messages. Figure 3 shows some examples.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing “search”. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

News for Creating Web UIs

Extensibility made easy with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is made much easier since we introduced the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard. The latest update introduces the ability to create an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension.

Figure 4: Creating an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension. Alt Text: Screenshot showing step 1 “Extension” task where users can select from a row of four cards “Custom Field”, “Custom Logic”, “Custom Process” and “User Interface Extension”. The latter has a subtext “Adapt the current application or extend it visually with a new application”. The latter two cards have a link “Manage SAP Build Projects” at the bottom. The bottom right shows two buttons “Next” and “Cancel”.

Learn more here:

  • SAP Build Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter

UI5 linter is the tool of choice to check your UI5 project for using best practices and replacement of deprecated SAPUI5 APIs. With UI5 linter v1.12.0, we are happy to announce the initial version of an autofix feature: Use the "--fix" argument to let UI5 linter apply fixes to your code automatically. Read more about it here:

  • Migrate your code with UI5 linter – Autofix has landed.

Legacy-free version of SAPUI5 available via cloud access

Once you have removed code which uses deprecated SAPUI5 APIs, you can try out the legacy-free version of SAPUI5 in the cloud, which has all deprecated code removed. Discover the benefits and how to try it out in this blog post:

  • Explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don’t accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging – so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2

SAP Fiori tools – open source, faster app creation, more AI

One of the most powerful recent innovations is the AI-powered project accelerator from SAP Fiori tools, which allows you to create a fully functional app with database tables, CDS-Views, OData service and a Fiori element list report UI based on a sketch of what you want. I introduced this in my Q1 update post from March. This can now be started from Joule in SAP Build Code. Also, it has been further enhanced, and is also available as open source, so that our developer community can make contributions themselves. Find out more here:

  • From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps
  • SAP Fiori Application Generator Available in Open Source

For those of you developing in ABAP, we have introduced the new quick SAP Fiori application generator to create and deploy simple SAP Fiori applications from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse. Have a closer look:

  • Quickly Generate and Deploy SAP Fiori Apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse

To get an overview of these plus some additional enhancements, have a look at:

  • SAP Fiori tools 2506 update – Open source, faster app creation, adaptation boost, AI enhancements.

Enhancements for SAP Fiori Elements with OData V4

We are continuously enhancing SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements. I have picked two enhancements to highlight here for developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4, which are covered in the following subsections:

  • Support for inline edit for object pages.
  • Support for the analytical table on the object page.

Support for inline edit for object pages

You can now develop object pages where users can directly edit fields within facets, without having to first press the “Edit” button and go into edit mode. Figure 5 shows an example from a test application.

Figure 5: Inline editing of fields in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of part of an object page “Travel”, which is overall in display mode, but the field “Starting Date” has been selected and is editable, with a new entry made, and “Save” and “Cancel” icons next to the field.

Support for the analytical table on the object page

For applications where users need to be able to analyze the data in a table, for example grouping data and aggregating data, developers should use the analytical table rather than the responsive table.

These tables are often used for the “list” part of an SAP Fiori elements list report, which consists of a list and an object page for the details. Now, developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4 can include an analytical table into one of the facets of an object page. Figure 6 shows an example.

Figure 6: Analytical table in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of an object page with a facet “Journal Entries (4)” which contains an analytical table, where the entries are grouped by “Case Journal Entry”. One of the groups is expanded, showing two lines. Below them the sum of the debit column is shown for the expanded group, and below that for the entire table.

Further Updates for SAPUI5

As I described in part 1 of this series, we have introduced a new option to preview an upcoming SAPUI5 version for SAP Build Work Zone. This capability aims to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments:

  • Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone.

Key users can create consistent text changes with SAPUI5 flexibility. I described this in the context of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in part 2 of this series (section Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column). They can also easily change the labels used, to fit terms established within the company. Read more about this here:

  • How Key Users Create Consistent Text Changes with SAPUI5 Flexibility.

SAPUI5 has reached a new milestone: it is now used on all 7 continents. Yes, we have reached Antarctica!

  • SAPUI5 adoption becoming more universal.

In case you have not updated your system for a while, then be aware that we are removing SAP Fiori themes Belize and Blue Crystal. Also, make sure that you are using the latest browser versions, which may mean ensuring that your users laptops and desktops are using newer operating system versions:

  • Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal
  • Prevent an SAP Fiori / SAPUI5 Downtime — Check Your Browser Strategy Today!

To get a complete overview of all the enhancements in SAPUI5 including SAP Fiori elements, look at the UI5 demo kit. You’ll find some of the enhancements mentioned above listed under version 1.136.

  • What’s New in SAPUI5.

 

News for Mobile Designers and Developers

The main news for mobile designers are the new SAP Design System portal, which covers Android and iOS as well as the latest releases of the mobile Figma design kits for Android, iOS, WatchOs and WearOS.

Figure 7: The Android and iOS pages in the new SAP Design System portal. Alt Text: Both screenshots look the same, except for Android vs iOS text. The top has a “Get Started” section, with a row of cards to navigate to UI Elements, UI Kit, Development Documentation. Below that a “What’s New” section, with information about the latest release “SAP Fiori for Android version 25.8” and “…for iOS…”.

The best place to stay up-to-date with these latest enhancements is the respective What’s New section in the SAP Design System portal:

  • SAP BTP SDK for iOS 25.4: What’s new for SAP Fiori for iOS
  • SAP BTP SDK for Android 25.8 (design preview) and 25.4: What’s new for SAP Fiori for Android

Figure 8 shows two of the many new enhancements: the new illustrations mentioned earlier in the section on web UIs are also available for mobile, both for iOS and Android. The other example shown there is the updated date picker for Android, which now allows users to select date ranges.

Figure 8: On the left, an example of the new illustrated messages for mobile. On the right, date ranges can now be selected in the date picker for Android. Alt Text: The illustrated message is used in a pop-over. The illustration shows a sheet of paper with a tickmark, below that the text “You’re all caught up…” and two buttons “Add Task” and “Remind Me Later”. On the right two date screens are shown for the month of April: the left one has the 8th marked, the right one has the range from 8th to 16th marked.

Developers get new features with the latest releases of the mobile SDKs, as well as the the Mobile Development Kit (MDK) which is integrated into SAP Build Code. Here are links to find out more about them:

  • What’s new in Mobile development kit client 25.6, for example:
    • Support grouping in Object Table Control
    • Donut chart support
    • … and more.
  • Continuous Innovation in Mobile Design & Technology: SAP Fiori for Android and iOS 25.4
  • SAP BTP SDK for iOS: What’s New in 25.08
  • SAP BTP SDK for Android 25.4.0 is now available

 

Final words

As you can see from all seven posts in the series, we continue to progress rapidly with the user experience of our product portfolio, especially with regards to AI-assistance.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

For general information on design at SAP and SAP Fiori, check out:

  • www.sap.com/design.
  • www.sap.com/fiori.
  • SAP Community: SAP Fiori topic page.

entry.title: Rise With the Phoenix: Your SAPUI5 Coding Journey Using the Demo Kit
entry.content:
The long, hot summer vacation days are coming to an end. It is the beginning of September, and the busiest period of the year for business has begun.

You are sitting relaxed at your spacious desk, in your favorite chair, looking at your monitor, and getting ready to do what you love: Start coding.  Today, you have a new idea that you want to turn into reality, and you want to do this fast: Code with SAPUI5. Maybe you have an SAP Fiori project coming up in the pipeline, or maybe you want to enter the world of SAP enterprise application development.

So, where should you start learning about SAPUI5 coding? The answer is simple, although initially, your task might seem overwhelming because a quick search on the topic returns hundreds of results.

One of the top search results would most likely be https://ui5.sap.com/, which is indeed the number one, comprehensive resource for improving your SAPUI5 coding skills.

The SAPUI5 SDK, or the Demo Kit, is the one-stop shop for modern developers who want to build state-of-the-art enterprise-grade SAP applications.

Think of the Demo Kit as the comprehensive code playground and learning hub for everything related to SAPUI5. It is built and maintained by hundreds of professionals who have dedicated their careers to building one of the most extensive, secure, and robust web application frameworks.

So, to save valuable time, go to the Demo Kit now and start your coding journey:

1. You will find extensive documentation covering the essentials, developing and extending apps, developing controls, and a What’s New section for all the latest and greatest features and functional capabilities in the most recent version of SAPUI5.

2. The Get Started: Setup, Tutorials, and Demo Apps section includes the foundational, legendary Walkthrough Tutorial, which, according to many in the SAPUI5 world, is the best resource for starting your SAPUI5 journey. The tutorial is available for JavaScript and TypeScript.

3. The API Reference section contains extensive information about all classes, interfaces, namespaces, and functions available within the SAPUI5 framework.

4. Browse, run, and download the Control Samples.

5. In the Demo Apps section, run tests, оpen and download apps, and explore UI5 Concepts in real-life scenarios.

6. The Resources section features dozens of curated development tools, troubleshooting tools, and customization toolboxes, including:

  • Icon Explorer: The right icon conveys more than words. Browse SAP’s extensive collection of icons to find exactly what fits your app’s context and message. 
  • Accessibility Guide: Create apps that are inclusive by design. The Accessibility Guide offers best practices and hands-on examples, whether you're a developer, UX designer, or business user. 
  • Card Explorer: Learn how to use integration cards – widget-like components ideal for dashboards and overview pages. 

Ready? OK, sit tight in your chair, plug in the headset with your favorite concentration music, open the Demo Kit, start your coding journey with SAPUI5, and… rise like the phoenix.

One more thing: Please tell us what’s on your mind. In the top right corner of the Demo Kit, you will find a “Feedback” icon. You can share your thoughts with us and help improve the Demo Kit.

The Demo Kit is also available for OpenUI5.

entry.title: SAP Fiori Tools Update – First Release of the SAP Fiori MCP Server for Agentic AI Workflows
entry.content:
We’re excited to announce the release of the SAP Fiori MCP server, a new capability that lets AI coding assistants directly create and edit SAP Fiori applications. This marks the next milestone in our AI journey, following the Project Accelerator introduced earlier this year.

What is MCP — and why it matters?

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard that standardizes how applications provide context to large language models. MCP is already supported by clients such as Claude, Cline, Cursor, and VS Code allowing AI-powered workflows to interact seamlessly with developer tools.

Introducing the SAP Fiori MCP server

The SAP Fiori MCP server (@sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server) is an open-source node.js module delivered as part of the open-ux-tools repository. It enables developers using AI coding assistants to generate and adapt SAP Fiori elements applications with precision and context awareness.

It is not the only MCP server published by SAP. The CAP MCP server (@cap-js/mcp-server) provides tools to create and modify CAP node.js projects, and the UI5 MCP server (@ui5/mcp-server) allows AI assistants to write SAPUI5 code. Together, these servers provide complementary entry points into different areas of SAP application development, so that AI assistants can seamlessly data models, SAP Fiori applications, and SAPUI5 code.

For more information also have a look at the related blog posts:

  • Boost your CAP Development with AI: Introducing the MCP Server for CAP
  • Give Your AI Agent Some Tools: Introducing the UI5 MCP Server

With the MCP servers in place, you can already try out scenarios such as:

  • “Please add an SAP Fiori elements list report app to my CAP project.”
  • “Generate a new CAP project and SAP Fiori app based on my_sketch.png.”
  • “Add Flexible Column Layout to the app.”
  • “Enable initial load for the SAP Fiori app.”

⚠️ Note: The SAP Fiori MCP server is currently released in experimental state and subject to rapid change and enhancements.

AI assistants can discover and act on SAP Fiori projects

The first release comes with a set of capabilities designed to let AI assistants both discover and act on SAP Fiori projects. The SAP Fiori MCP server provides tools to generate SAP Fiori elements applications for CAP node.js projects, finds SAP Fiori applications in the workspace, and allows to edit applications and pages inside applications.

To ensure that the AI produces correct results, we propose rules that guide the LLM’s behavior (see rules). These rules cover important aspects such as using proper SAP Fiori elements application patterns, ensuring data models are valid with UUID primary keys, generating sample data consistently, and preferring code-based modifications over screen personalization.

You can configure the server to be directly called with npx or install it globally via npm (see usage). In both cases, it integrates easily into an MCP-enabled client such as Cline.

Example how the SAP Fiori MCP server is used in Cline.

Developers can build apps more quickly using MCP servers

By connecting directly into SAP Fiori projects through MCP, developers gain a much more cost-effective way to experiment with AI support. They can let LLMs execute complex tasks in context—while the built-in functions and rules ensure adherence to SAP Fiori best practices. This reduces the risk of hallucinations, accelerates prototyping, and makes it easier to iterate quickly on new ideas. Since the SAP Fiori MCP server is with other MCP servers like UI5 and CAP, developers can benefit from a consistent AI-driven experience across different parts of the development process.

This is the first step on the MCP journey

The current release is just the first step. We are already working on extending the server with a document search feature that will make guidance from SAP documentation, tutorials, and examples directly available to the LLM. This means that the AI assistant won’t just follow rules embedded in the server but can also draw from the wealth of published learning content.

In addition, the generator functionality, which in the first release is limited to CAP node.js projects, will be expanded to support any suitable OData source. This will significantly broaden the scenarios in which the SAP Fiori MCP server can be applied, giving developers much more flexibility in how they use AI to create and adapt applications.

Try the SAP Fiori MCP server at SAP TechEd 2025

You can experience the SAP Fiori MCP server live at SAP TechEd Berlin. In session CA261 – Create great UX with AI, SAP Design System, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5, we’ll guide you through using AI and MCP to generate applications, adapt them, and extend them with SAPUI5. It’s a hands-on workshop designed to show how these new capabilities come together in practice.

Closing

This release marks the start of a new era in SAP Fiori development, where AI assistants can not only suggest but also execute tasks reliably. With upcoming enhancements like doc search and broader generator support, we’re laying the groundwork for smarter, faster, and more flexible AI-driven development. As an open-source project we also welcome your contributions. We encourage you to report any issues you encounter. Your feedback is invaluable to us.

We can’t wait to see how you experiment with it—and we look forward to meeting you at TechEd!

entry.title: An SAP UI5 application to Export Data to Excel sheet (Spreadsheet) from SAP UI5 table (sap.ui.table)
entry.content:
Hi SAP UI5 family,

    In this article, we are going to understand how to implement  export functionality the sap.ui.table table data to the excel(Spreadsheet) using  sap.ui.export.Spreadsheet library. In this application, we are going to create an SAP UI5 free style application which has sample employee JSON data that has been binded to the UI table and a toggle button has been added to trigger the export or downloading the excel data.
   
This is step by step guide to create a fiori application with SAP UI5 UI table and Export Button
Step 1: Create a Fiori Project

To begin, create a new SAP Fiori project using the  Fiori Generator Freestyle - Basic template. This will serve as the foundation for our application.

Application Folder Structure: 

Step 2 : Create a Dynamic Page , add UI Table Details and Add the sample JSON Data in controller 

  In TableView.view.xml, Add this code and add the Sample JSON data model object in the onInit() in TableView.Controller.js .

TableView.view.xml

<mvc:View
    controllerName="exporttoexcelex1.controller.TableView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns:m="sap.m"
    xmlns="sap.ui.table"
    xmlns:f="sap.f"
>
    <f:DynamicPage>
        <f:title>
            <f:DynamicPageTitle >
            <f:heading >
              <m:Title level="H2" text="SAP UI5 - Example : UI Table To Excel Export" />
            </f:heading>

            </f:DynamicPageTitle>
        </f:title>
        <f:content>
            <Table
                id="exportTable"
                rows="{/modelData}"
                enableColumnFreeze="true"
                selectionMode="Single"
            >
                <extension>
                    <m:OverflowToolbar>
                        <m:Title text="{i18n>title}" />
                        <m:ToolbarSpacer />
                        <m:ToggleButton id="export_btn" text="{i18n>export_btn}" icon="sap-icon://excel-attachment" press="onExcelExport"/>

                    </m:OverflowToolbar>
                </extension>
                <columns>
                    <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>name}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text  text="{Name}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                     <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>dept}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text text="{Department}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                     <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>buiAddress}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text text="{BuiAddress}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>phone}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text text="{Phone}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                </columns>
            </Table>
        </f:content>
    </f:DynamicPage>
</mvc:View>

TableView.controller.js

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel",
    "sap/m/MessageToast",
    "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet"
], (Controller, JSONModel, MessageToast, Spreadsheet) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("exporttoexcelex1.controller.TableView", {
        onInit() {
            var oView = this.getOwnerComponent();
            var oDataModel = new JSONModel();
            var oData = {
                modelData: [
                    {
                        "Name": "Raghu",
                        "Department": "Finance",
                        "BuiAddress": "Hyderabad",
                        "Phone": "+919234521532",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Mani",
                        "Department": "Technology",
                        "BuiAddress": "Bangalore",
                        "Phone": "+919234523423",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Krishna Priya",
                        "Department": "Technology",
                        "BuiAddress": "Hyderabad",
                        "Phone": "+919434345226",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Ester",
                        "Department": "Finance",
                        "BuiAddress": "Chennai",
                        "Phone": "+91945345226",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Niraj",
                        "Department": "Finance",
                        "BuiAddress": "Hyderabad",
                        "Phone": "+91945345226",
                        "Editable": false
                    }
                ]
            }


            oDataModel.setData(oData);
            oView.setModel(oDataModel);
        },
      
    });
});

Step 3 : Implement the press event trigger of the Export To excel Button
   Add this logic in controller.js . "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet" is the library should be used for excel export.
TableView.controller.js

onExcelExport: async function (oEvent) {
            //  "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet" is the library that has been used here
            var oTable = this.byId("exportTable");
            // get Rows of the Table
            var oBinding = oTable.getBinding("rows");
            // get Columns of the Table and get the Header labels and Property values 
            var aCols = oTable.getColumns().map(function (oColumn) {
                var sProperty = oColumn.getSortProperty();
                if (!sProperty) {
                    var oTemplate = oColumn.getTemplate();
                    sProperty = oTemplate && oTemplate.getBindingPath("text");
                }
                return {
                    label: oColumn.getLabel().getText(),
                    property: sProperty,
                    type: "String"
                };
            });
            var iLength = oBinding.getLength();
            // getting Data of the Table
            // use getContexts() for odata V2
            // use requestContexts() for odata v4
            var aContexts = await oBinding.getContexts(0, iLength);
            var aData = aContexts.map(function (oContext) {
                return oContext.getObject();
            });
            // settings for the Spreadsheet
            var oSettings = {
                workbook: {
                    columns: aCols,
                },
                dataSource: aData,
                fileName: "Exported Data.xlsx",
                worker: false
            };
            // getting new Spreadsheet object and binding the settings
            var oSpreadsheet = new Spreadsheet(oSettings);
            oSpreadsheet.build().then(function () {
                MessageToast.show("Exported excel data successfully ...");
            }).finally(function () {
                oSpreadsheet.destroy();
            })
        },

Application Screen:

ExportData.xlsx

Conclusion: 
By following these steps, The SAP UI table can be exported to spreadsheet or Excel sheet


Thanks and Regards,
Sree Vedavyasa Rangarajasree

entry.title: SAP UI5 Illustrations: Enhancing UX with Purposeful Visuals
entry.content:
What Are SAP UI5 Illustrations?

SAP UI5 illustrations are visual elements that complement written messages in the user interface. They’re not just decorative—they’re purposeful, designed to:

  • Simplify complex concepts
  • Create emotional connection
  • Guide users through unfamiliar workflows
  • Add personality to otherwise sterile enterprise screens

These illustrations are typically paired with messages in empty states, onboarding flows, error pages, or help dialogs. Think of them as visual metaphors that make abstract ideas more relatable.

Why Are They Necessary?

Here’s why illustrations are more than just eye candy in SAP UI5:

1. Improved Comprehension

Visuals help users grasp concepts faster than text alone. For example, an illustration of a magnifying glass next to a “No results found” message instantly conveys the idea of search failure.

2. Emotional Engagement

Enterprise apps can feel impersonal. Illustrations add warmth and friendliness, making users feel more comfortable and confident—even when something goes wrong.

3. Consistency Across SAP Fiori Design

SAP UI5 illustrations follow the SAP Fiori Guidelines ensuring a consistent look and feel across apps. This consistency builds trust and reduces cognitive load.

4. Accessibility and Inclusivity

Illustrations can support users with different language proficiencies or cognitive styles. When paired with clear text, they make the interface more inclusive.

5. Guided User Journeys

In onboarding or help flows, illustrations act as visual signposts. They guide users step-by-step, reducing friction and improving adoption.

Common Misuses to Avoid

SAP’s guidelines emphasize that illustrations should never:

  • Be used purely for decoration
  • Obstruct the user’s path
  • Replace essential information

They should always support the message, not distract from it.

️How to Use Them in SAP UI5

SAP UI5 provides a set of predefined illustrations via the sap.f library. Developers can easily integrate them using controls like IllustratedMessage, which combines an image, title, and description in a clean layout.

Example usage:

<sap.f.IllustratedMessage
    illustrationType="sapIllus-NoData"
    title="No Data Available"
    description="Try adjusting your filters or check back later." />

UI5 API Reference for Illustration

https://ui5.sap.com/#/api/sap.m.Illustration 

Illustration Samples

https://ui5.sap.com/#/entity/sap.m.IllustratedMessage/sample/sap.m.sample.IllustratedMessageInPageTNT

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP Incentive Management for Real-time Incentive calculation
entry.content:
Integrating SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management creates a powerful solution for real-time incentive calculation and sales performance optimization. Here's a breakdown of how this integration works and the benefits it offers:

Integration Overview

The mashup between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management enables sales teams to:

  • View real-time incentive data directly within the Sales Cloud interface.
  • Access a unified dashboard showing opportunities, leads, commissions, and payouts.
  • Receive instant updates as deals progress, with incentive data refreshed in real time.
  • Gain actionable insights into how performance affects earnings and what actions can maximize incentives.

Key Benefits

  1. Real-Time Insights & Motivation

    • Sales reps can see their commissions and performance metrics instantly.
    • Features like commission estimates, leaderboards, and performance dashboards help boost motivation.

  2. Streamlined Dispute Resolution

    • One-click traceability allows quick resolution of compensation inquiries.
    • Reduces administrative overhead and keeps reps focused on selling.

  3. Optimized Incentive Plans

    • Use AI-driven recommendations to refine compensation strategies.
    • Identify opportunities for bonuses or accelerators to maximize ROI.

  4. Flexible Plan Design

    • Easily model and test complex incentive plans using drag-and-drop tools.
    • Roll out new promotions without heavy IT involvement

Implementation Highlights

  • Once integrated, users can navigate to Sales History → Opportunities in SAP Sales Cloud V2.
  • A new dashboard section appears showing incentives and payments.
  • The mashup is enabled via standard configuration steps provided by SAP.

Integration Flow Description

  1. SAP Sales Cloud V2

    • Opportunity is created and assigned to a Opportunity Owner (Sales Employee).
    • Opportunity data includes total revenue,opporuntiy date, product, and stage.

  2. Employee Sync

    • The Employee in Sales Cloud is synced with SuccessFactors via master data integration.
    • Employee is linked to a Position in Incentive Manager.

  3. SuccessFactors Incentive Management

    • The Position is mapped to an Incentive Plan.
    • Incentive Plan defines rules, rule elements including quotas, accelerators, and payout logic.

  4. Real-Time Calculation

    • As the Opportunity progresses, incentive calculations are triggered.
    • Sales reps can view estimated commissions, performance dashboards, and leaderboards directly in Sales Cloud.

  5. Feedback Loop

    • Incentive results are sent back to Sales Cloud for visibility.
    • Managers can adjust plans or resolve disputes using traceable data.

entry.title: Additional Preconditions for Procurement Flexible Workflow
entry.content:
Introduction: The Custom Fields and Logic Fiori app in SAP S/4HANA is a powerful tool for in-app extensibility, enabling key users to modify standard applications without requiring extensive technical development. The Custom Fields and Logic app has been deprecated in favor of the Custom Logic (App ID: F6957) app in SAP S/4HANA. In present we are using Custom Logic Fiori app to implement Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) and behavior extensions for released business objects.

This blog aims to assist you in adding preconditions (such as Account Assignment, Plant, and Cost Centre) for Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions Fiori App. These standard fields must be displayed in the F4 help or dropdown menu for selection. To fulfil this requirement, we will implement two BAdIs (Business Context ID: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF, SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_EVAL).

 Step-by-Step Process:

Step 1 – Open SAP Fiori launchpad and search for Custom Logic App. 

Step 2 –Click on the Custom Logic tile and you will see the below screen and click on Create Button.

Step 3 - Enter the Business Context ID: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF in search input box, then click on Step2 button.

Step 4 - In Implementation Attributes, give the filter value(Scenario ID: WS02000458) using ADD button and save it.

entry.title: How SAP Fiori transforms the user experience in Public cloud
entry.content:
Hello Readers,
Today we will discuss about, How SAP Fiori transforms the user experience in Public cloud.

Now a days businesses want software that is not only powerful but also easy to use. SAP Fiori makes SAP systems user-friendly and simple to work.

What is SAP Fiori?
SAP Fiori is SAP's revolutionary user experience, design language that completely transforms how people interact with SAP software. Instead of the traditional complex SAP screens with multiple fields and confusing navigation.

How Fiori Transforms your Daily Work?

  1. Works on any Devices-
    • Work on your Smartphone and Tablet anywhere, as it is portable to carry.
    • Access everything from your laptop at home.
  2. No Training required-
    • Easy to learn for new employees.
    • Employees enjoy using the software.
  3. Personalized for business-
    • Business most used applications appear front.
    • Customizable dashboard shows what matters to business.
    • Smart notifications.

SAP FIORI used in various business process such as:

Market Survey Insights: Why Move from Traditional SAP Screens to Fiori?

  1. According to market surveys, most businesses face the same challenge with traditional SAP GUI are as:
    • Complex to use as complex screens with hundreds of fields.
    • Limitations using Mobile as interfaces weren't designed for smartphones and tablets
    • Productivity loss as simple tasks took multiple steps and screen navigation.
  2. According to Studies those organizations using Fiori experience:
    • Higher user satisfaction as Fiori works on any device and looks modern user interface.
    • Improved decision-making with built-in, real-time analytics.
    • Lower training costs as the interface is easy to learn in a less time.
    • 30 to 40% faster task completion due to intuitive, role-based design.

Disadvantages:

  • Role & Authorization maintenance as miss or wrong roles can block app access.
  • Slower in poor internet connectivity areas.
  • More Setup efforts as Requires backend & frontend configuration.
  • Requires supported browsers as performance varies if outdated.
  • Limitations in customization and app-to-app navigation.
  • End user using GUI need adaptation time to learn Fiori tiles.

How SAP Fiori performs other Non-SAP products in user experience:

SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud gives a smoother and smarter experience than many other non-SAP products.

SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud delivers a cleaner, faster, and more connected user experience compared to many non-SAP systems. It gives each user only the apps and data they need, keeps the same look and feel across all business areas, and shows live information powered by SAP HANA.

Fiori works seamlessly on any device, connects all processes in one system to avoid data gaps, stays current with regular updates, includes built-in help, and provides strong, enterprise-level security-helping users work smarter and more efficiently.

How SAP Fiori Connects in the Background:

  • User Access: Open the Fiori Launchpad in a web browser using a secure connection (HTTP/HTTPS).
  • Front-End Layer: The launchpad, containing the app designs (SAPUI5), is hosted on the SAP Front-End Server or built into S/4HANA Public Cloud.
  • OData Communication: Clicking a tile sends a request through SAP Gateway using OData services.
  • Backend Processing: The Gateway passes this request to the S/4HANA backend, which runs the ABAP business logic using tools like CDS views, BAPIs, or function modules.
  • Database Access: The backend retrieves or updates information from the SAP HANA database in real time.
  • Return Path: The data is sent back through the Gateway and displayed in your browser by SAPUI5.
  • Security: Access is secured with methods like SAML 2.0, OAuth, or SAP Logon Tickets, and controlled through roles and permissions.

In Public Cloud, all these components (Fiori, Gateway, backend logic, and database) are part of one system, making the process faster, seamless, and secure.

Conclusion: SAP Fiori transforms the SAP experience from complex, desktop-bound screens to a modern, intuitive, and mobile-ready interface. It improves productivity, reduces training time, and delivers real-time insights—helping users work smarter and faster. While it requires proper setup and stable internet, its seamless integration, consistent design, and role-based personalization make it a clear upgrade over both traditional SAP GUI and many non-SAP solutions. In the Public Cloud, its built-in architecture ensures speed, security, and a unified user experience across all devices.

entry.title: How to use MessageManager in SAPUI5 - Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
What is MessageManager?

The MessageManager in SAPUI5 helps us to manage and display messages like errors, warnings, or informational notes in our application. These messages often appear in a MessagePopover or directly next to form fields, giving users real-time feedback.

Let’s go through step by step to understand how we can use MessageManager effectively in our SAPUI5 app.

 

Step 1: Register the View with MessageManager

Before displaying any messages, we need to register our view with the MessageManager. This tells SAPUI5 to monitor form fields and automatically bind any messages to the right controls.

Add this line in the init function of our Component.js (or) Main.view.xml:

sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().registerObject(this.getView(), true);

Screenshot 1.1

Please Note: If  we're using manifest.json, there's also a declarative way to register it, but for simplicity, we’re going with manual registration here.

 

Step 2: Add a MessagePopover Control

To show the messages visually, add a MessagePopover in our view. We can do this in XML or JavaScript.

XML Example:

<Button text="Show Messages" press="onOpenMessagePopover" />

Screenshot 1.2.1

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used Main.view.xml for button which could trigger the validation based on the user input on this form fields.

<MessagePopover id="messagePopover" items="{ path: '/messages' }">
    <items>
        <MessageItem type="{type}" title="{message}" 
            description="{description}" />
    </items>
</MessagePopover>

Screenshot 1.2.2

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate fragment for for MessagePopover which could pop up when while validation has been called off.

 

Step 3: Add Messages to the MessageManager

Whenever we want to show a message (e.g., an error if a form field is empty), use the addMessages() method:

sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().addMessages(
    new sap.ui.core.message.Message({
        message: "Please fill all required fields.",
        type: sap.ui.core.MessageType.Error,
        target: "/field", // Optional: bind to a specific field
        processor: this.getView().getModel()
    })
);

Screenshot 1.3

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate method as addErrorMessage to add dynamic error messages for multiple forms.

Available Message Types:

  • Error
  • Warning
  • Success
  • Information

 

Step 4: Open the MessagePopover

When the user clicks the button (or at the right moment in our flow), open the MessagePopover:

onOpenMessagePopover: function (oEvent) {
    if (!this._oMessagePopover) {
        this._oMessagePopover = this.byId("messagePopover");
    }
    this._oMessagePopover.openBy(oEvent.getSource());
}

Screenshot 1.4

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate fragment for for MessagePopover which could pop up when Button has been triggered. (ex. while user clicks the submit button without filling the mandatory fields)

 

Step 5: Clear Messages

If needed (e.g., after a successful save), we can clear all messages like this:

sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().removeAllMessages();

Screenshot 1.5

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate method as removeErrorMessage to remove dynamic error messages.

 

Complete Flow - Here’s the full flow in a nutshell:

  1. Register our view with the MessageManager
  2. Add a MessagePopover control
  3. Insert messages into the MessageManager
  4. Trigger the MessagePopover on user interaction
  5. Clear messages when appropriate

 

Complete Code: (For Reference)

MessageManager.controller.js

sap.ui.define([
  "./BaseController",
  "sap/ui/core/message/Message",
  "sap/ui/core/Fragment"
],

  function (BaseController, Message, Fragment) {
    "use strict";

    return BaseController.extend("testapp.controller.MessageManager", {
      onInit: function () {
        var oMessageManager, oView;
        oView = this.getView();

        oMessageManager = sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager();
        oView.setModel(oMessageManager.getMessageModel(), "message");

        oMessageManager.registerObject(oView, true);
      },

      onOpenMessagePopover: function (oEvent) {
        var oSource = oEvent.getSource();

        this._createMessagePopover().then(function (oMessagePopover) {
          oMessagePopover.openBy(oSource);
        });
      },

      _createMessagePopover: function (oEvent) {

        var oView = this.getView();

        if (!this._pMessagePopover) {
          this._pMessagePopover = Fragment.load({
            id: oView.getId(),
            name: "testapp.fragment.MessagePopover"
          }).then(function (oMessagePopover) {
            oView.addDependent(oMessagePopover);
            return oMessagePopover;
          });
        }
        return this._pMessagePopover;
      },

      addErrorMessage: function (sMessage, sTarget) {
        var oMessage = new Message({
          message: sMessage,
          type: MessageType.Error,
          target: sTarget,
          processor: this.oModel,
          activeTitle: true
        });
        sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().addMessages(oMessage);
      },

      removeErrorMessages: function () {
        sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().removeAllMessages(
          new Message({
            target: "/uiDataInput",
            processor: this.oModel
          })
        );
      },

      onContinue: function (oEvent) {
        const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
        if (!this.uiOrderFieldValidation()) {
          oSource.setBusy(true);
          Promise.resolve().finally(() => {
            oSource.setBusy(false);
          });
        }
      },

      uiOrderFieldValidation: function () {
        let bOrderHasErrors = false;
        this.removeErrorMessages();
        const oResourceBundle = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("i18n").getResourceBundle();

        var sErrorMessage = oResourceBundle.getText("ORDER_FORM_ERROR_MESSAGE_GENERAL");
        const sFirstName = this.oModel.getProperty("/uiDataInput/firstname");
        if (!sFirstName || sFirstName.trim().length === 0) {
          const sNameErrorMessage = oResourceBundle.getText("ORDER_FORM_ERROR_MESSAGE_USER_FIRSTNAME");
          this.addErrorMessage(sNameErrorMessage, "/uiDataInput/firstName");
          sErrorMessage = sNameErrorMessage;
          bOrderHasErrors = true;
        }

        const sLastName = this.oModel.getProperty("/uiDataInput/lastName");
        if (!sLastName || sLastName.trim().length === 0) {
          const sLastNameErrorMessage = oResourceBundle.getText("ORDER_FORM_ERROR_MESSAGE_USER_LASTNAME");
          this.addErrorMessage(sLastNameErrorMessage, "/uiDataInput/lastName");
          sErrorMessage = sLastNameErrorMessage;
          bOrderHasErrors = true;
        }

        //Similarly you can check for all the remaining fields

        return bOrderHasErrors;
      }

    });
  });

 

MessageManager.view.xml

<mvc:View controllerName="testapp.controller.MessageManager"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc" displayBlock="true"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core"
    xmlns:l="sap.ui.layout"
    xmlns:u="sap.ui.table"
    xmlns:f="sap.ui.layout.form"
    xmlns="sap.m">
    <Page class="sapUiSizeCompact sapUiContentPadding" showHeader="false">
        <Panel headerText="Validation check using Message Manager" backgroundDesign="Transparent"
            class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom">
            <f:SimpleForm backgroundDesign="Transparent" editable="true"
                layout="ResponsiveGridLayout" labelSpanL="3" labelSpanM="3"
                labelSpanS="12" adjustLabelSpan="true" emptySpanXL="0" emptySpanL="0" emptySpanM="0"
                emptySpanS="0" columnsL="1" columnsM="1"
                singleContainerFullSize="false">

                <f:content>
                    <Label text="First Name" required="true" />
                    <Input type="Text" width="18.5em" maxLength="30"
                        value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/firstName', 
                                    type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                    constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 30 }}" />

                    <Label text="Last Name" required="true" />
                    <Input type="Text" width="18.5em" maxLength="30"
                        value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/lastName', 
                                    type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                    constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 30 }}" />
                    </HBox>
                    <Label text="Contact Number" required="true" />
                    <HBox>
                        <HBox width="27em" justifyContent="End">
                            <Input type="Number" width="25em" maxLength="30"
                                value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/contactNumber', 
                                        type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                        constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 30 }}" />
                        </HBox>
                    </HBox>
                    <Label text="Email Address" />
                    <HBox>
                        <HBox width="27em" justifyContent="End">
                            <Input width="25em" maxLength="241"
                                value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/emailID', 
                                        type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                        constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 241 }}" />
                        </HBox>
                    </HBox>
                    <Label text="Address" />
                    <TextArea height="7em"
                        value="{globalModel>/uiDataInput/address}"
                        rows="3"
                        width="25em"
                        liveChange="onTextAreaLiveChange"
                    />
                </f:content>
            </f:SimpleForm>
        </Panel>


        <Toolbar>
            <Button text="BACK" visible="false"
                class="sapUiSmallMarginBegin sapUiMediumMarginTopBottom"
                type="Emphasized" press=".navToOverview" />
            <ToolbarSpacer />
            <Button
                icon="sap-icon://alert"
                text="{= ${message>/}.length }"
                visible="{= ${message>/}.length > 0 }"
                type="Emphasized"
                press=".onOpenMessagePopover" />
            <Button text="NEXT"
                class="sapUiTinyMarginEnd sapUiMediumMarginTopBottom"
                type="Emphasized" press="onContinue" />
        </Toolbar>
    </Page>
</mvc:View>

 

MessagePopover.fragment.xml

<core:FragmentDefinition
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">
    <MessagePopover
        items="{message>/}"
        initiallyExpanded="true"
        activeTitlePress=".onActiveTitlePressed">
        <MessageItem
            activeTitle="true"
            type="{message>type}"
            title="{message>message}"
            subtitle="{message>additionalText}"
            description="{message>description}"/>
    </MessagePopover>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

 

Real World Scenario

Let’s say a user submits a form without filling all the required fields:

  1. You add error messages to the MessageManager.
  2. The messages automatically link to the empty fields.
  3. When the user clicks Show Messages, the MessagePopover displays all the issues clearly.
  4. After correcting the errors, you can clear all messages and proceed.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! 

If you found this helpful, feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments! Let's keep learning and growing together. 

Dear experts, I’m new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: Reducing Weeks to Minutes: AI, ABAP, and Low-Code in SAP Development
entry.content:
Introduction

The creation of SAP applications has always required a combination of technical and functional knowledge. In many scenarios, ABAP developers need to master SAPUI5 to deliver modern, SAP Fiori-style applications that meet end-user expectations.

However, the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools with low-code platforms opens a new path: enabling ABAP developers to build complete applications without needing SAPUI5 knowledge, while still allowing continuous maintenance in a simple and secure way.

Tachyonix has developed an innovative approach that transforms business specifications into technical specifications through specialized AI tools, significantly accelerating the development process and drastically reducing delivery time.

Architecture

  • Flow with LLM

  • Flow with Tachyonix Builder

How ABAP Integration with AI Works
