The flow begins with a specification provided by the user. For example: “I need a report that shows pending sales orders.”

From this request, different AI tools are triggered (these are some examples):

  • ABAP Package Tool: identifies the correct technical package where the application will be created.

  • Data Source Tool: selects the best source of data, indicating one or more relevant CDS Views.

  • Field Retrieval Tool: suggests the most appropriate fields to compose the application’s main list, based on the user’s description.

  • Floorplan Tool: recommends the visual structure of the application (for example, Master-Detail).

After these agents work together, a consolidated JSON containing the full technical specification is generated. This artifact is then used by the application creation agent:

  • Application Creation Tool: automatically builds the application according to the selected floorplan and the technical specifications provided by the other tools.

This flow allows complete applications to be created without manual programming, while still adhering to SAP best practices and design standards.

Integration with the Tachyonix Low-Code Platform

The main differentiator lies in the integration of this automation with the Tachyonix low-code platform. The generated application is not delivered as rigid, hard-to-maintain source code. On the contrary — it remains fully editable and extensible, allowing ABAP developers to continue evolving the solution without dealing directly with SAPUI5 or JavaScript.

This approach differs from what is sometimes called vibe-coding, in which an LLM directly generates source code. In the Tachyonix model, the LLM does not generate code. Instead, it produces structured technical specifications, which are then processed by a creation agent. This design ensures:

  • Security and predictability of the result.

  • Ease of maintenance and customization.

  • No risks associated with unreadable or unsupportable generated code.

Practical Advantages

  • Speed: a process that could take weeks is reduced to minutes.

  • Productivity: developers spend only a few hours making final adjustments and personalizations.

  • Accessibility: even without SAPUI5 expertise, ABAP developers can deliver modern applications.

  • Flexibility: applications evolve continuously within the low-code platform, without technical barriers.

Knowledge Graph as AI Support

At the time of writing this article, SAP Joule does not yet provide a public API for external consumption. For this reason, Tachyonix developed its own Knowledge Graph, which brings together SAP business scenarios.

This repository is used as a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) mechanism, ensuring that the LLM always has access to reliable, contextual information throughout the process.

Conclusion

The combination of ABAP tools with a low-code platform represents a significant step forward for the ABAP community. This approach does not replace the developer — it empowers them. With it, value can be delivered faster, more securely, and more sustainably, even without SAPUI5 knowledge.

In a market where time is a competitive advantage, solutions like Tachyonix reduce development cycles from weeks to minutes and establish a new paradigm for SAP application development.

As we are discussing AI, I leveraged HeyGen, an AI-based video creator, to demonstrate the process

entry.title: SAP TechEd 2025 - Go Mobile!!!
entry.content:
SAP TechEd in 2025 kicks off on November 4th in Berlin, and preparations are in full swing! This premier tech conference is perfect for developers, IT professionals, business experts, and tech visionaries to deepen their knowledge of SAP solutions and connect with peers and SAP experts. 

We have prepared an exciting offering of mobile sessions for you: Strategic Talks, Roadmap and Hands-on sessions on Mobile Apps, Mobile Design and Mobile Technology. Furthermore, we will have a demo booth where you can explore our apps an Mobile Joule on your own. 

Certainly Mobile AI, is the focus topics this year. 

Here are some of the sessions I’m most looking forward to this year:

CA200 | An overview of our AI-enhanced mobile products across SAP Business Suite - Deep Dive
View demos of selected apps and learn how the latest mobile apps from SAP make it easier for your users to leverage SAP Business Suite on the go. You can build your own mobile apps the same way we do—start by exploring how we use SAP Design System for mobile apps as well as the latest technologies such as the Joule copilot and SAP Build solutions.  

ST112 | AI and the future of product and user experience on the web and mobile - Strategy Talk
Discover how the Joule copilot and embedded AI are transforming UX as well as how you can use AI to enhance and extend the UX for SAP Business Suite. See our strategy for giving users access to all they need and enabling them to provide feedback, wherever they are, through the web and on mobile, including applications and central services.

CA811 | User and product experience innovations by SAP—on the web and mobile - Road Map
Have a look at the latest user and product experience innovations across our suite of applications, along with cool innovations coming soon—on the web and mobile. Also, check out selected highlights from UI technologies.

AD170 | Build scalable enterprise mobile solutions with SAP Build - Hands-on Workshop
Dive into the technical details of building scalable, cross-platform mobile solutions with SAP. Get a hands-on overview of integrating SAP Build solutions and our mobile development kit to streamline your development process and deliver high-quality apps.

CA260 | Learn how to build your own app and use it in SAP Mobile Start - Hands-on Workshop
Build an application on SAP BTP using SAP Build Code and SAP Cloud Application Programming Model that integrates with SAP Mobile Start. Accelerate development with development productivity tools in SAP Business Application Studio. Learn how to make the app accessible and send push notifications for relevant business events directly to your users.

CA201 | Creating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System - Deep Dive
Discover how AI is changing the idea of what an application is—and what this means for you. Learn about how to create AI-enhanced UX for your applications by using SAP Design System (SAP Fiori UX for web and mobile), and see how building applications is made easier through our AI UI technologies for web and mobile apps.

AD109 | Bridging the gap: Build your enterprise mobile strategy - Deep Dive
Are your employees struggling to find critical company data on the go? The SAP Mobile Start app solves that challenge by connecting them to SAP Build Work Zone and enabling custom mobile solutions. Find out how to create a powerful, integrated mobile journey for increased productivity.

AI166 | Mobile projects with SAP Joule for Consultants and SAP Joule for Developers - Hands-on Workshop
Learn how SAP Joule for Consultants accelerates execution of mobile projects and cloud transformation by simplifying knowledge access and offering expert guidance. Also, explore SAP Joule for Developers and its mobile development kit AI capabilities—including code suggestions, explanations, test generation, and more—to boost development efficiency.

CA914 | AI-based user and product experience innovations on the web and mobile - Demo Station
Experience the latest user and product experience innovations by SAP, including the Joule copilot on mobile devices and AI-embedded scenarios. Learn how you can leverage SAP Design System and our UI technologies to build your own apps. 

Do not miss this opportunity and join us in Berlin. Register now! 📅November 4 - 6, 2025 Berlin 
We look forward to meeting and interacting with you!

entry.title: 🚀 Mastering the Essentials: Your Journey into SAP S/4HANA Starts Here!
entry.content:
The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA: From Core Concepts to End-to-End Processes

Welcome to your all-in-one guide to navigating and mastering SAP S/4HANA! 👋

This guide is designed for everyone, from absolute beginners (Dummies and End Users) getting their first look at SAP, to Key Users who need to understand processes more deeply, and even Consultants looking for a clear, process-driven overview.

We'll start with the basics of logging in and navigating the system, build a solid understanding of the foundational structures and master data, and then walk through complete, real-world business scenarios from start to finish. We will focus on the modern SAP Fiori user experience, which provides a simple and intuitive interface, while also providing the classic SAP GUI transaction codes for those who need them.

Let's begin our journey to mastering SAP S/4HANA! 🚀

Part 1: Getting Started with SAP S/4HANA

This first part covers the essential skills you need to interact with the system. We'll explore the modern user interface, learn how to log in securely, and understand the different ways to navigate to the tasks you need to perform.

Chapter 1: The SAP S/4HANA User Experience

SAP S/4HANA offers two primary ways to interact with the system: the modern, web-based SAP Fiori Launchpad and the classic SAP Graphical User Interface (GUI).

SAP Fiori Launchpad

The Fiori Launchpad is the recommended and most modern way to use SAP S/4HANA. It’s a role-based, personalized, and real-time user experience.

  • Role-Based: You only see the applications (called "apps" or "tiles") relevant to your job. A purchasing agent will see apps for creating purchase orders, while an accountant will see apps for managing financial journals.
  • Intuitive Tiles: Apps are represented by tiles, which can display live information. For example, a tile might show "20 Open Invoices" without you even having to open the app. * Web-Based: You can access it from any device with a web browser, making it highly flexible.

SAP Graphical User Interface (GUI)

The SAP GUI is the classic interface that has been used for decades. While Fiori is the future, many advanced tasks and configuration activities are still performed in the GUI. It's a powerful tool, and understanding it is still very valuable.

  • Transaction Codes: The primary way to navigate is by using short, four-character "transaction codes" (T-codes).
  • Structured Menus: It uses a traditional folder-based menu structure.
  • Configuration Hub: The IMG (Implementation Guide), accessed via transaction code SPRO, is the central point for system customization and is accessed through the SAP GUI.

For the rest of this guide, we will provide both the Fiori App Name and the SAP GUI T-Code where applicable.

Chapter 2: Your First Logon and System Navigation

Let's get you into the system. The process is straightforward and secure.

Prerequisites

Before you can log on, your system administrator must provide you with:

  • Your

User ID (e.g., JSMITH)

  • An initial

Password

  • The

Client number (a three-digit number that represents a self-contained unit in the system, like 100)

First-Time Logon Process

The first time you log in, you will be required to change your initial password. This ensures your account is secure.

  1. Launch SAP Logon: Double-click the "SAP Logon" icon on your desktop. This opens a window listing the available SAP systems.
  2. Select System: Choose the correct system (e.g., S/4HANA Production) and click "Log On."
  3. Enter Credentials: On the logon screen, enter the Client, your User ID, and the initial Password you were given.
  4. Language: You can specify a language using a two-character code (e.g., EN for English).
  5. Press Enter. A dialog box will appear, prompting you to create a new password.
  1.  

Set New Password: Enter your chosen new password in the New Password field and repeat it in the Repeat password field to confirm. Click

Confirm.

  1. Copyright & System Messages: You may see a copyright notice or system messages from your administrator. Click

Continue to proceed.

Result: You are now logged into the SAP S/4HANA system! You will be greeted by the SAP Fiori Launchpad or the SAP Easy Access screen if using the GUI.

Password Rules 🔒

When creating a new password, you must follow specific rules for security:

  • Length: It must be between 3 and 8 characters long.
  • Characters: You can use letters (a-z), numbers (0-9), and punctuation.
  • Restrictions:
    • Cannot start with

? or !.

    • Cannot start with three identical characters (e.g.,

111PASSWORD).

    • Cannot be one of your last five passwords.
    • Cannot be

PASS or INIT.

Chapter 3: Finding Your Way - Apps, T-Codes, and Menus

Now that you're in, how do you get to the right screen to do your work?

Using the Fiori Launchpad

  • Search Bar: The most powerful tool is the global search bar at the top of the page. You can search for apps, business objects (like a specific purchase order number), or transactions.
  • Groups: Apps are organized into groups on your homepage, such as "Sales Order Management" or "Supplier Invoices."
  • App Finder: If you have the permissions, you can use the App Finder to search the entire catalog of available apps and add them to your homepage.

Using SAP GUI Transaction Codes (T-Codes)

A T-code is a shortcut to any task in the system.

  • Command Field: The Command Field is the white input box at the top left of the SAP GUI screen. This is where you enter T-codes. * How to Use T-Codes:
    1. Place your cursor in the

Command Field.

    1. Type the T-code (e.g., ME21N to create a purchase order).
    2. Press Enter. The system will take you directly to that task's screen.
  • Helpful Command Prefixes:
    • /n + T-code: Ends your current task and opens the new one in the same window. (e.g., /nVA01).

Use this to avoid having too many windows open.

    • /o + T-code: Opens the new task in a new window (session), keeping your current one open.
    • /nend: Logs you out of SAP after a confirmation prompt.
    • /nex: Logs you out immediately without a prompt. Be careful with this one!

How to Find a Transaction Code

If you are on a screen and want to know its T-code:

  1. Navigate to the menu path:

System -> Status...

  1. A pop-up window will appear. The "Transaction" field in the "SAP Data" section shows the T-code for the current screen.

Part 2: The Enterprise Structure - The Backbone of Your Business

Before any transactions can happen, a company must be digitally mapped in SAP. This digital map is called the Enterprise Structure. It's the framework that represents your legal, logistical, and financial organization.

Chapter 4: What is the Enterprise Structure?

Think of it like the blueprint of your company. It defines how different parts of your business relate to each other. For example, it defines which plants belong to which legal entity, which sales teams can sell from which warehouses, and how everything is tracked for accounting purposes. A well-defined structure is critical for smooth operations and accurate reporting.

Chapter 5: Key Organizational Units in S/4HANA

Here are the most important building blocks you will encounter. The examples below are based on the configuration data provided.

  • Client: The highest level in an SAP system. It's a self-contained unit with its own set of master data and transactional data. You select this when you log in.
  • Company Code (CoCd): A legal entity for which a separate set of financial statements (like a balance sheet and P&L statement) is created. It is the central organizational unit in Financial Accounting.
    • Example: Company Code 1000 - SAP Best Practices.
  • Controlling Area (CO Area): An organizational unit used for cost accounting. It can include one or more company codes, allowing for cross-company cost management.
    • Example: Controlling Area 1000 is set up for cross-company-code cost accounting.
  • Plant: A physical location where products are produced, stored, or services are provided. It can be a factory, a distribution center, a warehouse, or a regional office. A plant is always assigned to a single company code.
    • Examples: Plant 1000 (Factory 1), Plant 1100 (Factory 2). Both are assigned to Company Code
  1.  
  • Storage Location (SLoc): A specific area within a plant where materials are stored. A plant can have multiple storage locations.
    • Example: Plant 1000 has storage locations 1010 (Warehouse), 1020 (Workshop), 1060 (Returns), etc.
  • Sales Organization (SOrg): Responsible for the sale and distribution of goods and services. It represents a selling unit and is responsible for product liability and customer claims.
    • Examples: 1000 (Domestic Sales Org.), 1100 (International Sales Org.).
  • Distribution Channel (DChl): The way in which products or services reach the customer. It defines how you sell.
    • Examples: 10 (Direct Sales), 20 (Wholesale).
  • Division (Dv): Used to group materials or services. It represents a product line.
    • Examples: 10 (Product Division 10), 20 (Product Division 20).
  • Sales Area: The unique combination of a Sales Organization, a Distribution Channel, and a Division. Customer-specific agreements and pricing are often set at this level.
    • Example: S.Org 1000 + Dist. Channel

10 + Division 10 is one sales area.

  • Shipping Point: A physical location in a plant from which goods are shipped.
    • Example: Plant 1000 is assigned Shipping Points 1000 and 100R (for returns).
  • Purchasing Organization (POrg): Responsible for procuring materials and services for one or more plants. It negotiates pricing and conditions with vendors.
    • Example: Purchasing Organization 1000.
  • Purchasing Group: An individual or group of individuals responsible for certain purchasing activities. They are the main point of contact for suppliers.
    • Examples: 100 (Group 100), 101 (Group 101).

Chapter 6: A Look at Configuration (For Key Users & Consultants)

How are all these units created and linked together? This is done through configuration.

On-Premise/Private Cloud: SPRO - The Implementation Guide (IMG)

For traditional S/4HANA deployments, configuration is done using transaction SPRO. This opens the IMG, a hierarchical tree of all the activities needed to customize the system.

  • Navigation: You navigate through the tree structure to find the specific activity you need.
    • Example: To define a plant, the path is SPRO -> Enterprise Structure -> Definition -> Logistics - General -> Define, copy, delete, check plant.
  • Assignment: After defining the organizational units, you must assign them to each other.
    • Example: The path to assign a plant to a company code is SPRO -> Enterprise Structure -> Assignment -> Logistics - General -> Assign Plant to Company Code.

Public Cloud: Central Business Configuration (CBC)

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, configuration is managed through a web-based tool called Central Business Configuration (CBC).

  • Guided Procedures: CBC uses a scope-based, guided approach. You select pre-configured business processes (called Scope Items), and the system helps you configure them.
  • Project-Based: Configuration is done within a project, allowing for better tracking and management of changes.
  • Self-Service: It is designed to be more user-friendly, enabling customers to manage more of their own configuration.

Part 3: Master Data - The Foundation of All Processes

If the Enterprise Structure is the blueprint of your house, Master Data is the furniture and the people in it. It is the core information about your business entities that is used across all transactions. It's created once and used repeatedly.

Chapter 7: Business Partner (BP) - The New Standard

This is one of the most important changes in SAP S/4HANA. Previously, you had separate objects for Customers (XD01) and Vendors (XK01). Now, both are created as a single object: the Business Partner.

  • Single Point of Truth: A company that is both your customer and your supplier can be represented by a single BP number, eliminating data redundancy.
  • Roles: You create a general BP with a name and address, and then extend it to different BP Roles.
    • General Role (000000): Basic information like name, address, bank details.
    • Customer Role (FLCU00): Contains financial accounting data (company code level).
    • Customer (Sales) Role (FLCU01): Contains sales data (sales area level).
    • Supplier Role (FLVN00): Contains financial accounting data (company code level).
    • Supplier (Purchasing) Role (FLVN01): Contains purchasing data (purchasing organization level).
  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data
  • GUI T-Code: BP

Chapter 8: Material Master - The Heart of Logistics

The Material Master contains all information about a material (a product or service). This data is organized into different "views," each corresponding to a different business function.

  • Fiori App: Create Material / Manage Product Master Data
  • GUI T-Code: MM01 (Create), MM02 (Change), MM03 (Display)

Key Material Types:

  • ROH (Raw Materials): Purchased externally, used in production.
  • HALB (Semi-finished Goods): Produced in-house, used to make other products.
  • FERT (Finished Goods): Produced in-house, sold to customers.
  • HAWA (Trading Goods): Purchased externally and resold without any change.

Key Views to Maintain:

  • Basic Data 1 & 2: General data like material number, description, unit of measure, and weight.
  • Sales Views: Data for selling the material, like the delivering plant and tax information.
  • Purchasing View: Data for procuring the material, like the purchasing group.
  • MRP Views (1-4): Data for material requirements planning (MRP), like how the material is planned (e.g., MRP vs. consumption-based).
  • Accounting 1 & 2: Valuation data, such as the price control (standard or moving average) and the valuation class, which links the material to financial accounts.

Chapter 9: Other Key Master Data

  • Pricing Condition Records: This master data determines prices automatically in sales orders and purchase orders. It includes base prices, discounts, surcharges, freight, and taxes.
    • Fiori App: Manage Prices - Sales
    • GUI T-Code: VK11 (Create Sales), MEK1 (Create Purchasing)
  • Bill of Materials (BOM): A structured list of all the components needed to produce a parent product. It's the "recipe" for manufacturing.
    • Fiori App: Maintain Bill of Material
    • GUI T-Code: CS01 (Create), CS02 (Change), CS03 (Display)
  • Work Center: A location within a plant where production operations are performed. It contains data about scheduling, capacity, and costing related to an operation.
    • Fiori App: Manage Work Center
    • GUI T-Code: CR01 (Create)

Part 4: Core Business Processes - An End-to-End Journey

Now we'll put the structure and master data to work by walking through the three fundamental end-to-end scenarios in a typical business.

Scenario 1: The Procure-to-Pay (P2P) Process

This process covers all activities from needing a material to paying the supplier for it.

Process Flow: Purchase Requisition -> Purchase Order -> Goods Receipt -> Invoice Verification -> Outgoing Payment

  1. Create Purchase Requisition (Optional): A user formally requests a material. This is an internal document.
    • Fiori App: Create Purchase Requisition
    • GUI T-Code: ME51N
  2. Create Purchase Order: The requisition is converted into a Purchase Order (PO), a legal document sent to a supplier to procure goods or services.
    • Fiori App: Manage Purchase Orders
    • GUI T-Code: ME21N
  3. Post Goods Receipt: When the materials arrive at the plant, the warehouse clerk records the receipt against the PO. This increases inventory.
    • Fiori App: Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order
    • GUI T-Code: MIGO
    • Financial Impact: Inventory Account (Debit) | GR/IR Clearing Account (Credit)
    • EWM Integration: In a warehouse-managed scenario, this step triggers the creation of an inbound delivery in the Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) system, which then manages the putaway process.
  4. Enter Supplier Invoice: The accounting department receives the invoice from the supplier and enters it into the system, referencing the PO.
    • Fiori App: Create Supplier Invoice
    • GUI T-Code: MIRO
    • Financial Impact: GR/IR Clearing Account (Debit) | Vendor Payables Account (Credit)
  5. Post Outgoing Payment: The final step is to pay the supplier.
    • Fiori App: Manage Outgoing Payments
    • GUI T-Code: F-53
    • Financial Impact: Vendor Payables Account (Debit) | Bank Account (Credit)

Scenario 2: The Order-to-Cash (O2C) Process

This process covers all activities from a customer placing an order to receiving payment for the goods.

Process Flow: Sales Order -> Outbound Delivery -> Picking -> Goods Issue -> Billing -> Incoming Payment

  1. Create Sales Order: A sales representative receives an order from a customer and creates a sales order in the system.
    • Fiori App: Create Sales Orders
    • GUI T-Code: VA01
    • The system performs an Availability Check (ATP) to confirm if the goods can be delivered on the requested date.
  2. Create Outbound Delivery: The shipping department creates a delivery document, which is the trigger for all subsequent shipping activities.
    • Fiori App: Manage Outbound Deliveries
    • GUI T-Code: VL01N
    • TM/LE Integration: This step is the starting point for Transportation Management (TM) or Logistics Execution (LE). A transportation requirement is created, which is then used to plan freight, select a carrier, and tender the shipment.
  3. Pick the Goods: The warehouse operator picks the goods from the storage location.
    • GUI T-Code: LT03 (Create Transfer Order for the Delivery)
    • EWM Integration: The outbound delivery is replicated to EWM, which creates a warehouse task. Operators use mobile devices to execute this task, and upon completion, the information is sent back to S/4HANA.
    • HUM Integration: If Handling Unit Management (HUM) is active, materials are packed into handling units (e.g., boxes on a pallet), each with a unique number for detailed tracking.
  4. Post Goods Issue: This is the final step in shipping. It legally transfers ownership of the goods, reduces inventory, and updates the sales order status.
    • Fiori App: Post Goods Issue for Delivery
    • GUI T-Code: VL02N
    • Financial Impact: Cost of Goods Sold (Debit) | Inventory Account (Credit)
  5. Create Billing Document (Invoice): The billing department creates an invoice for the customer.
    • Fiori App: Create Billing Documents
    • GUI T-Code: VF01
    • Financial Impact: Customer Receivables Account (Debit) | Sales Revenue Account (Credit)
  6. Post Incoming Payment: When the customer pays, the finance team posts the payment, clearing the open receivable.
    • Fiori App: Post Incoming Payments
    • GUI T-Code: F-28
    • Financial Impact: Bank Account (Debit) | Customer Receivables Account (Credit)

Scenario 3: The Plan-to-Produce (P2P) Process

This process covers all activities from forecasting demand to producing finished goods.

Process Flow: Demand Planning -> MRP -> Production Order -> Goods Issue -> Confirmation -> Goods Receipt

  1. Create Planned Independent Requirements (PIRs): The planning department creates a forecast of demand for a finished product.
    • Fiori App: Maintain PIRs
    • GUI T-Code: MD61
  2. Run Material Requirements Planning (MRP) Live: MRP Live runs on the in-memory HANA database, exploding the demand down through the BOM and calculating what raw materials need to be purchased and what semi-finished goods need to be produced, and when.
    • Fiori App: Schedule MRP Runs
    • GUI T-Code: MD01N
    • Result: The system generates Planned Orders (for in-house production) and Purchase Requisitions (for external procurement).
  3. Convert Planned Order to Production Order: The production planner reviews the planned orders and converts them into firm Production Orders, which is the official instruction to the shop floor to start manufacturing.
    • Fiori App: Manage Planned Orders or Convert Planned Orders
    • GUI T-Code: CO40 (Individual), CO41 (Collective)
  4. Issue Goods to Production Order: The warehouse provides the raw materials/components listed in the order to the shop floor.
    • Fiori App: Post Goods Movement
    • GUI T-Code: MIGO (Movement Type 261)
    • Financial Impact: Consumption Expense Account (Debit) | Raw Material Inventory (Credit)
  5. Confirm Production Order: The shop floor operators confirm the work they have done (time, quantities, etc.). This updates the order status.
    • Fiori App: Confirm Production Order
    • GUI T-Code: CO11N
    • CS/PM Integration: If a piece of equipment used in production requires maintenance, a notification can be created from the production order, triggering a process in Customer Service (CS) or Plant Maintenance (PM).
  6. Post Goods Receipt from Production: Once the finished product is complete, it is received into inventory from the production order.
    • Fiori App: Post Goods Receipt for Production Order
    • GUI T-Code: MIGO (Movement Type 101) or MB31
    • Financial Impact: Finished Goods Inventory (Debit) | Production Output/Settlement Account (Credit)
    • QM Integration: If Quality Management (QM) is active, this goods receipt can automatically create an inspection lot. The goods are posted to "Quality Inspection" stock and cannot be used until a QM technician inspects them and records a usage decision.

Part 5: The Comprehensive Test Plan

This test plan is designed to allow you, whether you are an End User, Key User, or Consultant, to practice and validate the core S/4HANA functionalities in a structured way. Use this plan to build confidence and ensure the system works as expected.

Introduction to Testing

The goal of this test plan is to simulate real business operations from start to finish. For each test case, follow the steps, use the provided test data, and record your actual results against the expected outcomes.

Test Scenario 1: Master Data Creation (The Foundation)

Objective: To ensure that fundamental master data can be created correctly, forming the basis for all subsequent transactional tests.

Test Case ID

TS-MD-01: Create a Business Partner (Supplier)

Objective

Create a new supplier (vendor) master record using the Business Partner transaction.

Prerequisites

You have the necessary authorizations to create Business Partners.

Test Steps

1. Go to Fiori App Manage Business Partner Master Data or T-Code BP. 2. Click on "Create" and select "Organization." 3. Select the BP Role Supplier (FI) (FLVN00). Click Create. 4. Enter a Name (e.g., Global Raw Materials Inc.), Address (Street, City, Country, Postal Code), and Language (EN). 5. Click "Save." Note the BP Number generated. 6. Re-open the BP in change mode. 7. Switch to BP Role Supplier (Purchasing) (FLVN01). 8. Go to the "Purchasing" tab. Enter Purchasing Org. 1000. 9. Enter the Order Currency (USD) and Payment Terms (0001). 10. Save your changes.

Test Data

BP Name: Global Raw Materials Inc. Purchasing Org: 1000

Expected Result

A Business Partner is created with both general data and purchasing-specific data. The system saves without errors.

Actual Result

(To be filled by the tester)

Pass/Fail

(To be filled by the tester)

Export to Sheets

Test Case ID

TS-MD-02: Create a Finished Good Material

Objective

Create a new material master record for a product that will be produced and sold.

Prerequisites

Enterprise Structure (Plant, Sales Org, etc.) is configured.

Test Steps

1. Go to Fiori App Create Material or T-Code MM01. 2. Enter a Material Number (e.g., FG-PUMP-1000) and Industry Sector Mechanical engineering. 3. Select Material Type FERT (Finished Good). 4. In the "Select View(s)" pop-up, choose: Basic Data 1 & 2, Sales Org. Data 1 & 2, Sales: General/Plant, MRP 1, Accounting 1. Click Enter. 5. Enter Organizational Levels: Plant 1000, Sales Org 1000, Dist. Channel 10. 6. Basic Data: Enter Description High-Pressure Water Pump, Base Unit PC, Material Group 001, Weight details. 7. Sales Views: Enter Delivering Plant 1000, Tax Classification (e.g., 1 for all tax types). 8. MRP 1 View: Enter MRP Type PD (MRP), MRP Controller 001. 9. Accounting 1 View: Enter Valuation Class 7920 (Finished Goods), Price Control S (Standard), and enter a Standard Price (e.g., 250.00). 10. Save the material.

Test Data

Material Number: FG-PUMP-1000 Plant: 1000 Material Type: FERT

Expected Result

The material master is created successfully and is available for use in planning, production, and sales processes.

Actual Result

(To be filled by the tester)

Pass/Fail

(To be filled by the tester)

Export to Sheets

Test Scenario 2: End-to-End Procure-to-Pay (P2P) Flow

Objective: To test the entire purchasing cycle, from creating a purchase order to paying the supplier.

Test Case ID

TS-P2P-01: Standard Procurement Process

Objective

Procure a trading good, receive it into inventory, and process the invoice and payment.

Prerequisites

A supplier (Business Partner) exists (use TS-MD-01). A trading good material exists (create one with type HAWA, e.g., HAWA-SCREW-KIT).

Test Steps

1. Create PO: Go to Fiori App Manage Purchase Orders (or ME21N). - Enter the Supplier number from TS-MD-01. - In the item overview, enter Material HAWA-SCREW-KIT, Quantity 100 PC, Plant 1000. - Enter Net Price (e.g., 5.00 USD). - Save the PO and note the number. 2. Post Goods Receipt: Go to Fiori App Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order (or MIGO). - Select "Goods Receipt" and "Purchase Order." - Enter the PO number. The data should populate. - Check the "Item OK" box and Post. Note the Material Document number. Check Point: Use Fiori App Display Stock Overview (or MMBE) to confirm that stock for HAWA-SCREW-KIT has increased by 100 in Plant 1000. 3. Enter Invoice: Go to Fiori App Create Supplier Invoice (or MIRO). - Enter Invoice Date. Enter the PO number in the reference field. - The amount should match the PO value (100 * 5.00 = 500.00). Enter this in the Amount field. - Simulate and Post the invoice. 4. Post Payment: Go to Fiori App Manage Outgoing Payments (or F-53). - Enter bank data, amount, and the supplier number. - Process the open item corresponding to your invoice. - Post the payment.

Test Data

Supplier: Global Raw Materials Inc. Material: HAWA-SCREW-KIT Quantity: 100 Price: 5.00 USD

Expected Result

The process completes without financial errors. The PO history is fully updated. The vendor's account balance is cleared. Inventory is correctly updated.

Actual Result

(To be filled by the tester)

Pass/Fail

(To be filled by the tester)

Export to Sheets

Test Scenario 3: End-to-End Order-to-Cash (O2C) Flow

Objective: To test the entire sales cycle, from receiving a customer order to collecting the payment.

Test Case ID

TS-O2C-01: Standard Sales Process

Objective

Sell a finished good from stock, ship it to the customer, and process the billing and payment.

Prerequisites

A customer (Business Partner) exists (create one with customer roles). The finished good from TS-MD-02 (FG-PUMP-1000) exists and has stock (you can add stock using MIGO with movement type 561).

Test Steps

1. Create Sales Order: Go to Fiori App Create Sales Orders (or VA01). - Enter Order Type OR (Standard Order). - Enter your Customer number, a PO Number (e.g., CUST-PO-123). - In the items, enter Material FG-PUMP-1000 and Quantity 5 PC. - Save the Sales Order and note the number. 2. Create Delivery: Go to Fiori App Manage Outbound Deliveries (or VL01N). - Enter Shipping Point 1000 and the Sales Order number. - The system creates the delivery document. Save it and note the number. 3. Post Goods Issue: Open the delivery in change mode (Fiori: Change Outbound Delivery, VL02N). - Go to the "Picking" tab, enter picked quantity as 5. - Click the Post Goods Issue button. Check Point: Check the stock overview (MMBE). Stock for FG-PUMP-1000 should be reduced by 5. Check the Document Flow in the sales order (VA03) to see all related documents. 4. Create Invoice: Go to Fiori App Create Billing Documents (or VF01). - Enter the Delivery document number and press Enter. - The invoice details are displayed. Save the billing document. 5. Post Payment: Go to Fiori App Post Incoming Payments (or F-28). - Enter bank details, amount, and the customer number. - Process the open item for your invoice. Post the payment.

Test Data

Customer: (Your created customer) Material: FG-PUMP-1000 Quantity: 5

Expected Result

The entire O2C cycle is completed. The Document Flow is complete from order to invoice clearing. Inventory and financial accounts (AR, Revenue, COGS) are correctly updated.

Actual Result

(To be filled by the tester)

Pass/Fail

(To be filled by the tester)

entry.title: How to change a git commit message safely
entry.content:
Introduction:

In Git, may be sometimes when we might want to change a commit message, whether it's to correct a typo or provide a more meaningful description or simply fix something we missed. Fortunately, git provides powerful tools to help with this.

 

Changing a commit message depends on the context:

  1. When the commit is the most recent
  2. When the commit is older
  3. When you want to keep the same message but add more changes to the commit

 

1. Change the Most Recent Commit Message:

If you just committed and haven’t pushed yet: git commit --amend -m "New commit message"

git commit --amend -m "New commit message"
  • This updates the last commit message.
  • Alternatively, If you omit the -m flag, git will open your default editor so you can edit the message there.

 Screenshot: 1.1

 

2. Change an Older Commit Message

To change a commit message further back in history, use interactive rebase: git rebase -i HEAD~n

git rebase -i HEAD~1
  • Replace n with the number of commits you want to go back (e.g., HEAD~1)
  • In the editor that appears, change pick to reword for the commit(s) whose message you want to update
  • git will then prompt you to enter a new message for each selected commit, modify it and save it (Refer screenshot 2.2 & 2.3)

 Screenshot: 2.1

 Screenshot: 2.2

  Screenshot: 2.3

 

3. Most Recent Commit Without Changing Its Message

To update the files or staging of your last commit while keeping the original message: git commit --amend --no-edit

git commit --amend --no-edit
  • This preserves the previous commit message, but lets you include new changes (e.g., add forgotten files - means stage the files, then run the above comment)
  • Useful when you've made minor updates and don't want to touch the commit message

 Screenshot 3.1

Please Note:

  • Use --force only if you're sure — this can impact collaborators on the branch.
  • If you’ve already pushed, changing commit messages rewrites history: git push --force
git push --force

Understanding how to change Git commit messages is essential for good version control, always use these commands carefully, especially on shared branches and communicate with your team before rewriting history.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! I hope this helps you improve your commit messages. If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback, or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Stay tuned for more Git-related commands in future blogs. Happy coding!

Dear experts, I’m new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: Join SAPUI5 Sessions at SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Dear UI5 enthusiasts,

SAP TechEd 2025 is where UI5 developers meet to enhance their knowledge and get hands-on experience. This is the type of content you like to see: Understand the strategy, see highlights and try out latest capabilities around SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements.

SAP TechEd in 2025 kicks off on the 4th of November 2025, and preparations are in full swing in SAP. As you probably know, SAP TechEd is the leading tech conference for all developers, IT professionals, business experts, eager to gain in-depth knowledge of SAP’s technologies. It also offers an excellent opportunity to network and connect with peers and SAP experts.

 

SAP TechEd 2025: Registration is live – check out our brand new hybrid experience!

Access the full SAP TechEd 2025 session catalogs:  SAP TechEd Berlin and SAP TechEd Virtual and see my shortlist here:

Keynote

KEY100 | Beyond the hype: How SAP is supercharging developers for what's next
Some experts argue there’s a developer shortage. Others will say developers are no longer needed due to AI. Let’s get real: developers, architects, and technologists are here to stay, and their roles are more important than ever.

Strategy Talks

ST117 | SAP’s user experience strategy with SAP Build
An intuitive user experience is essential for every business user. Examine SAP’s strategy for evolving SAP Build Work Zone to empower a streamlined digital workplace, and for building efficient SAP Fiori apps with SAPUI5. Hear how SAP is advancing with Joule, our AI copilot, now embedded across SAP Build solutions.

ST116 | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools - also available virtually as ST116v
Explore the most recent innovations in SAP Build solutions that help developers to create extensions, applications, and automations. Learn how enhancements in the development environment, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, and Joule copilot empower customers and partners to build extensions efficiently at scale.

Deep Dives

AD106 | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build - also available virtually as AD106v
Discover what’s new in SAPUI5 development with SAP Build solutions. Learn to build modern SAP Fiori apps across ABAP and the cloud using new developer tools, Joule technology integration, and proven SAPUI5 capabilities. Get insights into SAP’s UI strategy with SAP Web Components and see how you can benefit. Elevate your UI with SAPUI5 in SAP Build.

AD203 | Fact-checking UI extensibility on cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you
SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps in a clean core approach. Key users use drag-and-drop tools while developers add custom code with visual editors and the Joule copilot. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and ABAP RESTful application programming model help extend data models and add custom logic in SAP Build solutions.

AD100 | Joule for developers: How AI can boost your development in SAP Build
The Joule for developers add-on combines all the AI capabilities in SAP Build solutions. Learn about AI-driven development and how developer productivity can be increased. Developers can use our productivity tools to make their lives easier when engaging in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and UI development.

CA105 | Intelligent app development at scale with AI and SAP Fiori elements

With exciting updates to building blocks, a streamlined entry page, and powerful generative AI in SAP Fiori tools, developers can build applications faster than ever. Get a first look at how we integrate MCP to orchestrate AI capabilities across SAP Fiori tools and SAP Fiori elements for faster app development.

AD201 | Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build: What's in it for ABAP developers

Understand the importance of our strategic approach of integrating ABAP Cloud into SAP Build solutions. Find out how you can benefit from this for SAP Fiori app development and how the graphical modeler helps you to create ABAP core data services models conveniently. Finally, get insight into our future direction.

Roadmap Sessions

AD818 | Explore the road map for user experience with SAP Build
SAP Build solutions feature many new and upcoming user experience capabilities. Find out how SAP Build Work Zone delivers a connected, intuitive digital workplace, including the SAP Mobile Start app. Understand SAP's road map for building SAP Fiori apps with SAPUI5. See how the Joule copilot supports user and developer productivity.

AD820 | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions - also available virtually as AD820v
Check out upcoming enhancements to SAP Build solutions involving SAP’s professional developer tools, the Joule copilot, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAPUI5, and SAP Fiori apps. These updates boost developer productivity, support clean core, and improve extensibility for line-of-business (LoB) apps, advancing enterprise app development.

Hands-on Workshops

AD166 | Taking UI to the next level: Develop SAPUI5 with SAP Build
Use SAP Build solutions to develop a modern app with SAPUI5. Explore latest best practices, including the UI5 linter and TypeScript to build a future-proof app. Get to know SAP Web Components and leverage them in your SAPUI5 app. Gain hands-on experience, ask questions, and see how Joule technology supports you with AI-based SAPUI5 magic.

AD260 | UI extensibility on top of cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you
SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps with a clean core approach. Key users and developers can add custom code with visual editors and Joule technology. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and the ABAP RESTful application programming model support extending data models and adding custom logic in the SAP Build solution.

AD160 | Get hands-on with Joule: Boost your SAP Build development with AI
The Joule for developers add-on brings AI capabilities directly into SAP Build solutions to support your development process. Get hands-on experience using AI-driven tools to boost your productivity in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and UI development, with features designed to simplify your workflow and help you build faster and smarter.

CA261 | Create great UX with AI, SAP Design System, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5

Learn how to create new SAP applications with great UX and AI using the reusable components, patterns, and floor plans in SAP Design System. Design with the SAP Fiori for Web UI kit from Figma, harness AI and the MCP protocol for automated app generation and real-time adaptation of SAP Fiori elements, and extend freestyle in SAPUI5.

AD163 | Fusion development with ABAP Cloud in SAP Build

Practice fusion development of ABAP Cloud in SAP Build solutions by creating an ABAP Cloud project from the lobby for SAP Build to develop an ABAP RESTful application programming model business object, including an SAP Fiori app on top.

It sounds awesome, right? I KNOW!
See you there...

entry.title: A Hitchhiker's Guide to SAP Fiori User Experience and its Technologies – 2025 edition
entry.content:
I’m sure you’ve heard of SAP Fiori, the design system for all SAP products. SAP Fiori covers the design itself, the SAP Fiori applications delivered by SAP, but also technologies and tools to run those apps, to extend standard SAP apps or even to develop your own custom apps.

  • Are you looking for a high-level understanding of SAP Fiori and its technologies and tools?
  • Would you like to get an overview to see how all of this fits together?
  • Do you know which role SAP Build plays?
  • You have an ABAP / on-prem background and want to learn about how SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) / cloud is used for SAP Fiori?
  • Do you want to leverage entry points for your own practical learning, e.g. recommended tutorials?

Look no further. This 2-part webinar helps and provides entry points for your hands-on learning.

Agenda Part 1

SAP Fiori is the User Experience of SAP Business Suite that changes the way you work. In this overview you’ll get a first understanding of SAP Fiori: The SAP Fiori design system and how it is realized with the related UI technologies and tools, for business users, key users, and developers. This part covers the main environments like SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform. The overview extends to the actual productive usage of SAP Fiori business applications via an SAP Fiori launchpad, and the essential UI frameworks.

  • The SAP Fiori Design system
  • An overview of Technologies and Tools for SAP Fiori
  • The entry point to SAP Fiori: SAP Build Work Zone
  • The strategic UI frameworks SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements

Agenda Part 2

In the second part we’ll cover SAP Build for AI–based application development and, of course, look at ABAP development tools. This leads us to the important scenario of extensibility and how you can easily add custom extension to standard SAP apps. Mobile technologies and a Q&A section close the second part.

  • The SAP Build development environment and ABAP Development Tools in Eclipse
  • Extending standard SAP applications with Clean Core principles
  • Technologies for a mobile experience

Who Should Attend?

This overview session is for everyone, from executives to software developers. It is a complete run-through of SAPs user experience technologies, ranging from end user personalization to developer tools, from creating an initial project to productively using an app. This content is especially useful if you have an ABAP background and need a sound overview understanding of SAP Fiori and its tools and technologies. The webinar has a focus on providing the full picture and entry points into further learnings.

👉 Join me for this 2-part webinar, live on October 28. and 30., 17:00 – 18:00 CET on YouTube Part 1 and Part 2.

entry.title: Unlocking SAP Fiori and other business content on Mobile: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Introduction: Accessing SAP business content on mobile

While analysing the recent search queries from users around “the use of SAP on mobile” we came across the below examples.

  • is there an app for SAP Fiori? 
  • can I access SAP Fiori from mobile? 
  • how to use SAP Fiori on iPhone? 
  • can SAP be used in mobile? 
  • how to open SAP on mobile? 
  • what SAP business content is available on mobile?

There were also questions around how SAP Mobile Start fit into the picture with the standard set of mobile apps for each of the cloud solutions from SAP; for e.g. SAP SuccessFactors mobile.

Providing clarity on these kinds of questions served as the motivation for writing this blog. We will also look at the broader set of business content that can be accessed from mobile as standard or via configuration.

Is SAP Fiori Client still relevant?

The SAP Fiori Client mobile app provided a native runtime environment for SAP Fiori apps on iOS and Android devices.  It was removed from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store on March 31st, 2022. (Refer to SAP Note 2992772).

While the above SAP note does recommend the users of SAP Fiori to transition to SAP Mobile Start, the above search queries gave the impression that customers probably could do with bit more guidance on the overall strategy and approach around accessing SAP business content including SAP Fiori apps from mobile.

Decision tree for alternatives to SAP Fiori Client

As mentioned in the SAP Note 2992772, one of the options is for the users of SAP Fiori Client to transition to SAP Mobile Start. Here’s a visual representation of the decision tree for customers who are still using SAP Fiori Client as covered in SAP Fiori Client successor recommendations.

Product positioning of SAP Mobile Start

SAP Mobile Start is positioned as the mobile native entry point for business applications, processes and business data from SAP and non-SAP solutions. SAP Mobile Start was initially released for iOS (iPhone and iPad) in September 2021 and the Android version was later released in June 2022. This also signified a change in mobile strategy for SAP by moving away from the hybrid world to native app approach.

 

The mobile app for SAP's central entry point solutions

SAP Mobile Start brings the content that is deployed on SAP’s central entry point solutions to mobile users.

 

Once the business content is deployed on these solutions, you can enable the power of mobile to the end-users with a QR code scan at almost no additional implementation effort or deploy using Mobile Device Management (MDM).

 

Accessing SAP business content from mobile

Now let’s dive deeper into how the following types of business content can be deployed and consumed via SAP Mobile Start.

  1. standard business content from SAP S/4HANA that is mobile enabled
  2. custom SAP Fiori apps created using SAP Build
  3. custom native apps created using SAP mobile services
  4. other SAP business solutions content

1. SAP S/4HANA standard business content on mobile

Let’s address the question on how to access SAP S/4HANA business content (SAP Fiori roles and apps) via mobile.

  • SAP Fiori Apps Reference library can provide a list of SAP Fiori apps that are optimized for mobile phone and tablet. For e.g. you can discover apps “by Line of Business”; for e.g. Finance, Sourcing and Procurement etc.

 
  • You need to implement SAP Fiori roles and apps for your chosen processes on your SAP Fiori launchpad on SAP S/4HANA; refer to How to Deliver a Great User Experience with SAP S/4HANA.
  • You can then federate and bring the business content (SAP Fiori roles and apps) to one of the central entry point solutions mentioned above. Refer to the learning journey: Setting up SAP Mobile Start with SAP S/4HANA on SAP Build Work Zone which explains how to do this using SAP Build Work Zone and bring it to mobile.

You can also refer to below assets:

  • SAP Fiori Deployment Options and System Landscape Recommendations is the reference document for all consultants, partners and customers who implement SAP Fiori. Do note that it also mentions the use of SAP Build Work Zone as a central entry point deployment option.
  • SAP Fiori Deployment in 2025: Embedded vs. Work Zone Standard vs. Advanced Edition also gives some insights into comparing various deployment options.

2. Creating and consuming custom SAP Fiori apps

SAP Build is a unified application development and process automation solution, enabling personalization and efficiency at scale. You can create custom SAP Fiori apps, using SAP Build Apps (for low-code development) and SAP Build Code (for pro-code development). You can connect to your SAP S/4HANA or other backend system, use visual tools to define data models and UI elements, and leverage generative AI with tools like Joule to accelerate development.

SAP Build Work Zone can act as the central entry point to consume these custom apps as well as the federated (standard) business content from SAP S/4HANA. SAP Mobile Start can consume the content that is deployed on SAP Build Work Zone.

3. Creating custom mobile apps that follows SAP Fiori guidelines

Some customers may have use cases for which they might want to create custom native mobile applications that meets the following requirements:

  • utilize the native capabilities offered by the respective operating systems
  • while also following the SAP Fiori design guidelines
  • and maintaining the same user-experience as that of the business solutions from SAP.

This is where SAP Mobile Services comes into picture. It is an open standard based service on SAP Business Technology Platform that enables simple mobile application development, configuration, and management. It offers:

  • SAP Mobile Development kit which is a metadata driven tool that can allow you to develop cross platform applications.
  • Or SAP BTP SDKs for iOS as well as Android for those who want more flexibility beyond what the above metadata driven approach can provide.

These SDKs follow SAP Fiori design guidelines to preserve the familiarity of both the native operating system experience as well the SAP Fiori app experience; refer to SAP Fiori mobile design guidelines.

Any custom native app that you create can of course be launched from SAP Mobile Start via a native tile; refer to add native apps to your content.

4. Other SAP business solutions content

To be a true native entry point, SAP Mobile Start app also needs to bring the business content and key capabilities from other SAP business solutions to a mobile user.  Let's have a closer look at the possibilities.

  • SAP S/4HANA (as explained above)
    • mobile enabled apps from SAP S/4HANA SAP Fiori launchpad via content federation 
    • workflow notifications and situations
  • SAP Task Center integration for tasks; for e.g. Purchase Order approval from SAP S/4HANA. Also tasks from SAP Ariba , SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Cloud for Customer, SAP Concur, SAP Fieldglass, SAP Field Service Management, SAP Marketing Cloud, SAP Workflow Service, 3rd party providers
  • UI integration cards displaying Insights and custom cards
  • URL tile to Cloud solutions from SAP e.g. SAP Concur web
  • Analytical story from SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Native app tile to launch specialised app from the respective SAP Cloud solution
    • e.g. SAP Concur mobile
    • or deep links where SAP Cloud solution supports the same; e.g. using SAP SuccessFactors deep link to directly launch Compensation details
  • SAP Document AI integration

 

Big picture on SAP’s mobile portfolio

To complete the picture on SAP’s mobile portfolio, we must also talk about the dedicated mobile apps that comes with each of the cloud solutions from SAP ; for e.g. SAP SuccessFactors mobile, SAP Analytics Cloud mobile, SAP Concur mobile etc and how SAP Mobile Start fits into the picture.

SAP Mobile Start in the context of other SAP mobile apps

SAP Mobile Start is not intended to provide the ability for the end users to access all mobile enabled capabilities from all the cloud solutions from SAP. It is meant to be a native entry point from where the following can be done.

  • the most valuable capabilities and content from the business solutions can be accessed as described above.
  • and the specialised mobile apps provided by each of these cloud solutions from SAP can be launched.

 

Conclusion:

In summary

  • SAP Mobile Start is the mobile native entry point into SAP universe for a mobile user.
  • Administrators can deploy the most critical content from various business solutions from SAP as outlined above on SAP's central entry point solutions and bring them to SAP Mobile Start.
  • The end-users can further use the specialised standard SAP mobile apps.
  • SAP Mobile Services provides a choice of SAP BTP SDKs that can be used to create custom native apps when end-user needs go beyond the standard set of apps provided by SAP while also maintaining the familiarity of the respective operating system as well as SAP Fiori design guidelines.
  • The users of SAP Fiori Client are encouraged to move to SAP Mobile Start.

We look forward to hearing your experience with setting up these solutions in your landscape. We are keen to hear about mobile personas and use-cases you have taken advantage of. Please do share your thoughts and comments below.

Stay up to date with latest news and post your questions or feedback about SAP Mobile Start in the Q&A area. Start by visiting your SAP Mobile Experience community page and click “follow”. We’ll be publishing more informative blog posts.

entry.title: 5 Tips for Getting Started with the SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit
entry.content:
The SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit is your go-to resource for creating consistent, efficient, and accessible user interfaces. The kit helps you design faster without starting from scratch.

Here are five helpful tips to get started and design with confidence:


1. Explore the full component library first 

Before jumping into design work, begin with the design foundations separately, such as color, typography, and shadows. Understanding these basics early on will help you make better, more consistent decisions throughout your work. You’ll also find SAP icons and product illustrations integrated directly into the kit. 

Once you're familiar with the foundations, take time to explore the full set of components included in the file. The UI kit provides a wide range of ready-made elements, scalable and fully aligned with SAP’s design principles, all in one place. 


 2. Use variables to switch between themes easily 

In the SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit, variables control core style properties such as colors, typography, and spacing. 

The kit includes support for multiple themes that reflect SAP’s visual language in different environments. The default light theme is called Morning Horizon, and for low-light settings, the Evening Horizon theme provides a dark mode alternative. 



Using variables, you can switch between these themes easily within your Figma file. This lets you preview how your designs will look across different user preferences without rebuilding components from scratch. 


3. Use the Slot for content placement 

Some components, such as Dialogs or Cards, include a Slot - a clearly marked area (highlighted in orange) where you can insert your own content, like text, icons, or buttons, while keeping the original structure and behavior intact. 

To use it, simply select the Slot layer in the component and replace it with your own content using the “Swap instance” option in the right-hand panel. There’s no need to detach the component, your changes will stay consistent and maintain the design integrity. 
 

 
Using the Slot keeps your designs flexible, editable, and easy to maintain. 

 

4. Keep your file organized and use naming conventions 

Maintaining a well-organized file helps you and your team navigate and manage designs efficiently. Use clear naming conventions for frames, components, and layers so it’s easy to find and update elements later. This practice saves time and reduces errors, especially as your designs grow in complexity. 
 



5. Stay in sync with releases 

The SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit is actively maintained and regularly improved with new components, updates, and refinements based on user feedback. To stay up to date, keep an eye on official announcements and communications from the SAP Design team.  You can find the latest releases and enhancements on our SAP Design System Portal “What’s New” page. 

The SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit gives you more than a set of components, it provides a solid foundation for building enterprise-ready designs that scale.
